wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Jason Nemer and Jenny Sauer-Klein are credited with founding AcroYoga in 2003. Combining their backgrounds in yoga and acrobatics, they created a form of partner-supported yoga that has elements of performance art as well as physical and therapeutic value. They envision AcroYoga as a way to build human connections and create community by developing mind-body and interpersonal awareness.

AcroYoga is a fun, adventurous, and uniquely social yoga style that emphasizes teamwork and trust. Along with the physical benefits, it's a great way to conquer fears and build relationships. Though the advanced poses can be challenging, anyone can learn AcroYoga; just be sure to practice with a knowledgeable instructor and the proper safeguards. If it seems intimidating at first, it'll be that much more satisfying and empowering when you and you partner master those impressive flying poses!

AcroYoga is a creative fusion of yoga and acrobatics, often with elements of dance and/or Thai Yoga Massage. It is a type of Partner Yoga, in which partners support each other to achieve challenging inversions, dynamic balancing postures, and flying poses. These exercises help build core strength, flexibility, balance, concentration, and confidence. It is a playful and often therapeutic practice that encourages cooperation and trust among partners.

Afro Flow Yoga was developed in 2008 by professional dancer and yoga instructor Leslie Salmon Jones as a way to bring more cultural diversity into traditional yoga practice. Leslie's husband and co-founder Jeff W. Jones, a multi-instrumentalist and recording artist, creates the live African soundtrack for her classes. An Afro Flow Yoga teacher training program was initiated in 2014.

Afro Flow Yoga classes are open to all levels of yoga and dance experience and welcome students from all racial and cultural backgrounds. The classes celebrate diversity and encourage a judgement-free community where all students can find liberation and freedom in their bodies. The African dance and music elements bring an earthy, soulful vibe to the classes that is refreshing and grounding.

Afro Flow Yoga is a fusion of yoga and meditation with African dance and music. Flowing vinyasa sequences become rhythmic to the beat of the drum and incorporate expressive dance movements that emphasize freedom in the hips. Attention on the breath draws the awareness into the present moment, turning the yoga dance into a moving meditation. The practice is both energizing and peaceful.
Time To Yoga : Afro Flow Yoga

Ana Costa developed Anahata Yoga in 2001 after many years of practicing and teaching other yoga styles. Her special focus on opening the heart center was inspired by the teachings of her guru, Parmahansa Yogananda. Certified Anahata Yoga teachers now exist all over the world.

Anahata Yoga practice is designed to be simple, safe, and adjustable for all levels, ages, and physical conditions. Students are taught to modify postures and to use props as necessary. Teachers offer nurturing hands-on adjustments. The classroom atmosphere is non-judgmental and inclusive.

Drawing its name from the Sanskrit word for the heart chakra, Anahata Yoga is a classically-rooted yoga style that gives special emphasis to purifying and expanding the heart center, both physically and energetically. Yoga and breathing exercises that open the chest, shoulders and lungs invite the life force to flow through the body, freeing stagnant emotional energy and changing the defensive, caved-in posture to a courageous, heart-forward posture. Meditation and mindfulness practices teach students to connect with the deep wisdom of their hearts and the infinite spirit that resides there, awakening the heart's natural qualities of love, compassion, forgiveness, courage, joy and faith.
Discover the benefits of Anahata Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on Time to Yoga.

Swami Kriyananda created his "Ananda Yoga for Higher Awareness" system in the 1960s after a period of intensive yoga training in India with his guru, Paramhansa Yogananda, the creator of the Self-Realization Fellowship. Ananda Yoga is based on the Kriya Yoga tradition Yogananda practiced and taught, as well as on Yogananda's own innovations, particularly his Energization Exercises.

Ananda Yoga is an inward-directed practice that places emphasis on subtle energy awareness rather than on physical achievement for its own sake. Students are guided through a series of gentle Hatha yoga postures with attention placed on proper alignment and graceful transitions between poses. The asanas are practiced for their effect on the consciousness, and are accompanied by inner affirmations intended to enhance this effect. Classes also include Yogananda's 39 Energization Exercises designed to increase focus and control of the subtle energies within oneself, such as the energy of the chakras.

Ananda Yoga is a spiritually-oriented yoga practice that uses physical yoga postures (asanas), breathing exercises (pranayama), and silent affirmations in order to experience higher states of awareness and to recharge oneself with cosmic life-force. The philosophy and practice of Ananda Yoga draws on classical Hatha and Kriya yoga traditions as well as on the teachings of Parmahansa Yogananda, who taught that the human physiology is designed to act as a "battery" that can be "consciously charged from the unlimited supply of cosmic energy." Ananda Yoga practice is intended as a preparation for meditation.

Ananda Yoga Ananda Yoga instructor Ananda Yoga classes benefits of Ananda Yoga Alignment Energize and Improve Strength Improve Posture Inner Peace and Quiet Mind

John Friend founded the Anusara School of Hatha Yoga in 1997, drawing on his Iyengar Yoga training and incorporating aspects of Tantric philosophy from sacred Indian texts, while also articulating a unique set of Universal Principles of Alignment. The Anusara trademark is held exclusively by the ASHY, which is now independently managed by a global community of certified Anusara teachers.

Anusara Yoga classes offer an uplifting environment that emphasizes the inherent good in each student. Classes begin with a Sanskrit mantra invocation or a quiet moment of centering in recognition of the presence of Spirit. The physical practice focuses on precise alignment, in the tradition of Iyengar yoga, while also incorporating flowing Vinyasa-style movement sequences. Anusara Yoga has its own complex philosophy regarding physical alignment, the flow of energy in the body, and how these relate to consciousness, and these concepts are articulated through a unique lingo that takes some time to learn. You can expect to hear about energy loops, inner and outer spirals, and "opening to grace".

Anusara Yoga is a unique yoga style that infuses a physical Iyengar yoga practice with a spiritual philosophy drawn from the Tantra tradition. The word "Anusara" is taken from the Kularnava Tantra sacred text and translates as “following your heart” or “flowing with grace”. Anusara Yoga is based on a philosophy of benevolent Oneness underlying all things, and emphasizes the heart as the key to discovering this reality. Heart-opening Vinyasa Flow movements are practiced as a way to embody the awareness of one's divine nature and intrinsic goodness. Emphasis during practice is placed on the "three As": Attitude, or the spiritual intention behind one's practice; Alignment, or mindful awareness about the relationship between body and spirit; and Action, or the flow of energy in the body.

item.title: Ashiyana Yoga
item.content:encoded: Ashiyana Yoga offers a uniquely dynamic class by pairing traditional yoga postures with fluid, active movements. Through a combination of flow and static holds, students experience the spiritual and physical energetics of both motion and stillness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Students of various levels can practice Ashiyana Yoga. Classes consist of practicing sun salutations, varied postures, and meditation. During class, students are encouraged to respect their bodies' limitations.

Chris Nelson developed Ashiyana Yoga after studying the origins of yoga and its many forms during his Sivananda Teacher Training. He is an unconventional teacher whose classes are unplanned, whimsical, and do not follow a set sequence, allowing his creativity to flow.

Ashiyana Yoga fuses the asanas (poses) of Hatha Yoga with various dynamic positions. It strives to promote internal awareness and provide practitioners a fulfilling yoga experience for the mind, body and spirit.
Ashiyana utilizes meditation, differing postures and Sun Salutations to promote internal awareness and engage the mind, body and spirit.

item.title: Ashtanga Yoga
item.content:encoded: Ashtanga Yoga is the inspiration for several Vinyasa classes. Ashtanga Yoga is challenging, and functions on a foundation of classically-rooted exercises and ideals. The practice is uninterrupted and smooth, helping the learner to observe what arises without rejecting or holding onto it. The benefits of Ashtanga Yoga include improved strength, cardiovascular fitness, weight loss and improved energy levels.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: During an Ashtanga yoga class, students are encouraged to go through the posture sequences at their own pace, rather than in sync with the whole class. The teacher typically moves around the room and gives adjustments and personalized suggestions to facilitate optimal alignment and expression.

Ashtanga Yoga is a classically-rooted practice that has inspired a variety Vinyasa flow yoga styles. This style consists of brisk, agile, and athletic motions that flow through a fixed series of postures.  The practice is uninterrupted and smooth, helping the learner to observe what resistance arises in the mind without rejecting or holding on to it. Through continued Ashtanga practice, the skill of attentive non-attachment will spill over into all facets of life. Other benefits of this challenging practice include improved strength and energy, cardiovascular fitness and weight loss.

A student of Tirumalai Krishnamacharya, “the father of modern yoga,” K. Pattabhi Jois is credited with popularizing Ashtanga. André Van Lysebeth, a Belgian student of Jois, wrote a book on his experiences, which ignited popularity for this style among Westerners. Ashtanga is taught all over the world, and today the Shri K. Pattabhi Jois Ashtanga Yoga Institute is lead by Jois’ grandson, R. Sharath.
Ashtanga Yoga is an uninterrupted, smooth series of poses helping the learner to observe what arises without rejecting or holding onto it.
Discover the benefits of Ashtanga Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Atma Yoga
item.content:encoded: Atma Yoga is a heart- and holistic-centered approach to spiritual awakening through yoga. Atma Yoga recognizes that everyone is a channel of breath and the cosmic energy of life. Atma Yoga draws on teachings from Tantra, Bhakti, Ayurveda, and various other healing philsophies. The benefits of Atma Yoga include inner peace, enlightened living, and connection to higher consciousness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Atma Yoga was created by Saul David Raye to provide a practice that facilitates connecting with the Self and the Universal Spirit.

Atma Yoga classes take an exploratory and intuitive approach to well-being, combining dynamic Asana (poses), heart-wisdom teachings, meditation, breathwork, music, intuitive movement, and chanting to experience the many facets of one's spiritual, mental, emotional, and physical body. Students are invited to go at their own pace.

Atma Yoga is a holistic approach to creating spiritual, mental and physical well-being. Drawing on teachings from Tantra, Bhakti, Ayurveda, and other sacred traditions, Atma Yoga teaches that every soul is a channel of breath and cosmic energy.  Through a combination of physical engagement, attention to breath, and contemplation, Atma Yoga promotes an inner awakening to this sacred truth. The practice is intuitive and heart-centered, honoring every being’s unique creativity, spirit and self.
Atma Yoga is a holistic, heart centered approach, which draws from the teachings of Tantra, Bhakti, and Ayurveda.

item.title: Baptiste Yoga
item.content:encoded: Baptiste Yoga is a flowing practice, marked by a vigorous, physically challenging sequence of postures in a heated environment. Baptiste Yoga encourages practitioners to discover their own authentic personal power while cultivating peace of mind and a sense of freedom. The benefits of Baptiste Yoga include weight loss, improved strength, inner peace and higher energy.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Baron Baptiste created Baptiste Yoga after studying under several Indian yoga masters as well as his parents, yoga pioneers Walt and Magana Baptiste, who opened the first yoga center in San Francisco in 1955.

Baptiste Yoga classes are generally held in a heated room, and consist of a spirited 90-minute sequence which is designed to condition the entire body. Students can expect a challenging practice that will also help center mind, spirit, and body.

Baptiste Yoga is a powerful, physically challenging, flowing practice. It encourages practitioners to discover their edges, explore untapped personal power, and utilize non-judgment and self-compassion while doing so. Baptiste Yoga reinforces the importance of being present and maintaining peace of mind, even amidst challenge. Such a practice prepares its students to face philosophical and emotional challenges in all aspects of life.
Baptiste Yoga is a challenging, flowing practice sure to get a student’s heart going.

item.title: Benefit Yoga®
item.content:encoded: Benefit Yoga is strongly rooted in Yoga Therapy, Authentic Yoga, and Ayurveda. It is founded upon the idea that recognizing and respecting the interconnectedness of life is critical to obtaining inner balance and peace. Benefit Yoga emphasizes the need for a comprehensive understanding of the emotional, mental, physical, and spiritual aspects of yoga, as well as an awareness of the natural sciences and Ayurveda. The benefits of Benefit Yoga include healing, addressing and releasing trauma, and establishing a higher connection to oneself and the universe.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Benefit Yoga was created after 40 years of research and implementation of its philosophy and practice. It was developed to place asanas in ordered steps to aid in the transformation of health, enhanced behaviors, and attitudes.

A Benefit Yoga class is centered around the belief that two essential pillars of health include mindfulness and self-empowerment. In order to fully manifest these components of oneself, Benefit Yoga overlays traditional asanas (poses) with harmonizing breathwork and mantra. It strives to lead students toward inner calmness, self-discovery, and healing, with importance placed on free-flowing breath, meditation, intentional relaxation, and anatomy.

Benefit Yoga is strongly rooted in Yoga Therapy, Authentic Yoga, and Ayurveda. Benefit Yoga is founded upon the concept of holding high respect for the interconnectedness of life. It is a holistic approach, incorporating multidimensional work to help practitioners achieve balance on many levels. Benefit Yoga also emphasizes the need for a comprehensive education of the emotional, mental, physical, and spiritual aspects of yoga, and does this by drawing upon the teachings of such wide-ranging sources as biomedical science and Ayurveda.

Benefit Yoga is the result of 30 years of research into health, behavior, and attitude; it is a holistic approach to Yoga bringing harmonization of the body, breath, and mind, resulting in inner calmness and healing through self-discovery.
Discover the benefits of Benefit Yoga® and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Bikram Yoga
item.content:encoded: Bikram Yoga is designed to provide rigorous, full-body stimulation while requiring students to maintain mindful awareness and concentration. Bikram Yoga is performed in a room heated to 105 degrees and 40% humidity. The benefits of Bikram Yoga include improved strength and energy, increased flexibility, focus, clarity of mind and detoxification.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Bikram Yoga was introduced to the United States by Bikram Choudhury in 1971. He developed the Bikram system after training under Bishnu Ghosh from 1903 to 1970. The Bikram Yoga headquarters is maintained at The Bikram Yoga College of India in Los Angeles, California.

Bikram Yoga is practiced in a room heated to 105 degrees, with 45 minutes of standing poses and 45 minutes of floor postures. Each class consists of 26 different poses and two breathing exercises. The high temperature and humidity promote sweating, which is believed to aid in the detoxification and purification of the body's cells, organs, and energetics.

Bikram Yoga is a vigorous protocol of 26 set postures specifically designed to access every muscle, joint, and energetic channel within the body, while simultaneously requiring students to maintain full mental concentration. It aims to help create a physically fit, flexible body and sound mind, enabling the physical self to join with the spiritual self.
Mind and Body Benefits of Bikram
Bikram Yoga combines mental concentration with a strong physical workout in a heated room.
Discover the benefits of Bikram Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Body-Mind Centering
item.content:encoded: Body-Mind Centering utilizes an active approach to the body, consciousness, and movement. This style was created according to an experienced clinician's understanding of applied physiology and psychological development. Body-Mind Centering makes use of touch, movement, mind, and voice to assist with body/mind re-patterning. The benefits of Body-Mind Centering include inner peace, quietness of mind, improved focus, and mental clarity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Body-Mind Centering was developed by Bonnie Bainbridge Cohen. She is a registered movement therapist, registered occupational therapist, and a registered yoga teacher. She brings a unique understanding of human development to the practice, via additional certifications in Laban Movement Analysis, Kestenberg Movement Profiling, and Neurodevelopmental Therapy.

Body-Mind Centering provides a safe space to explore the mind and spirit through the avenue of the body. It utilizes specific principles which work to create a re-patterning in the body and mind. During class, students can expect elements of touch and movement, as well as use of the mind and voice.

Body-Mind Centering teaches an experiential approach to understanding the body, movement, consciousness, and their relationship to one another.  Drawing on principles from applied physiology and psychological development, Body-Mind Centering makes use of touch, movement, mind, and voice to assist with physical and mental re-patterning. The process is exploratory and personal, allowing students to gain an embodied understanding of the functioning of their own physiology, spirituality, and psychology.
Body-Mind Centering Yoga works to develop psychological processes in addition to physical, making use of touch, movement, voice, and mind in an active approach.
Discover the benefits of Body-Mind Centering and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Body-Mind Centering Body-Mind Centering instructor Body-Mind Centering classes benefits of Body-Mind Centering Balance and Flexibility Improve Focus and Clarity Inner Peace and Quiet Mind

item.title: Bollywood Vinyasa Yoga
item.content:encoded: Bollywood Vinyasa Yoga is a practice that draws upon both classical yoga postures and dance movements taken from India’s popular Bollywood style of cinema. This style allows students to stretch and tone their bodies while listening to entertaining and upbeat music. The benefits of Bollywood Vinyasa Yoga include increased energy, improved strength, inner peace, and joyfulness of spirit.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Bollywood Vinyasa was developed by Hemalayaa Behl, who practiced yoga and different Indian dance styles for many years. The combination of these influences has culminated in modern methods of fitness, such as Bollywood Cardio and Bollywood Vinyasa.

Bollywood Vinyasa Yoga is a creative fusion of classical yoga postures with modern dance movements taken from India’s popular Bollywood style of cinema. This fun, expressive yoga style allows students to stretch and tone their bodies while listening to entertaining, upbeat music.

Students of all levels can practice Bollywood Vinyasa Yoga. Classes are upbeat and full of energy. The hallmark of these classes is the music: a hybrid of hip-hop, Indian pop, and classical Indian music. These sounds provide the backdrop for an active Hatha yoga practice, which may be punctuated by belly dancing movements and modern dance.
Bollywood Vinyasa Yoga combines Bollywood dance movements and Yoga postures to stretch and tone the body in an entertaining and upbeat atmosphere.
Discover the benefits of Bollywood Vinyasa Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Curvy Yoga
item.content:encoded: Curvy Yoga is designed to provide plus-sized women a safe and serene environment to begin their yoga practice. Curvy Yoga consists of a specific teaching style based on positive communication and community support. The benefits of Curvy Yoga include increased balance, flexibility, muscle tone and weight loss.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Curvy Yoga classes focus on teaching yoga in a way that is peaceful, non-judgmental, and universally accessible, while staying true to the nature of yoga poses and philosophy.
Curvy Yoga was created by Anna Guest-Jelley, who after years of yoga practice wanted to create a style of yoga and a method of teaching geared toward curvy women.

Curvy Yoga is an inspiring, safe space for new students to embark upon a yoga practice. Specifically geared toward plus-sized women, Curvy Yoga aims to serve as a training gateway for curvy yogis and their teachers and allies. It provides a non-judgmental, serene atmosphere for students to begin to explore the mind-body connection through yoga. Curvy Yoga also contains a unique teaching style, which is based on productive, positive communication with oneself and with others
Curvy Yoga offers accessible and safe teaching for curvy women without straying from the essence and authenticity of traditional Yoga postures and exercises.

item.title: Detox Flow Yoga
item.content:encoded: Detoxification has been practiced for centuries in Chinese medicine, Ayurveda, and other healing traditions. Detox Flow engages students in postures that specifically work to detoxify the body, mind, and spirit by stimulating, purifying, and nourishing the body from the inside out. It seeks to promote reflection, to aid in releasing mental blocks, and to promote physical well-being.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Detox Flow Yoga is accessible to students of all levels. Postures range from slow and gentle twists and bends to an intermediate-level, flowing practice. Classes may include meditations, reflections, sun salutations, guided instruction, sequences, spiritual awakening, diet suggestions and more.
Detox Flow Yoga was developed by Seane Corn, an internationally-celebrated instructor who travels the world offering conferences, workshops and retreats to promote the message of healthy living.

Detoxification or "detox" methods have been practiced for centuries in Chinese medicine, Ayurveda, and myriad other traditional healing systems. Detox Flow yoga engages the body in deep twists and long holds that stimulate the body's circulatory, lymphatic and digestive systems, aiding the body's natural purification processes. Focused breathing exercises help oxygenate the body and clear the mind, encouraging reflection, release of mental blocks, and coordination of mind/body awareness.
Detox Flow Yoga cleans and nourishes the body through practices taken from Vinyasa Flow.
Discover the benefits of Detox Flow Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Dharma Yoga
item.content:encoded: Dharma Yoga focuses on the eight limbs and nine forms of yoga. Classes are designed to create a calm and peaceful environment, while improving a practitioner's overall health, mental well-being and connection to spirit. The benefits of Dharma Yoga include improved focus and clarity of mind, inner peace, body awareness, and improved self-esteem.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: After over 50 years of studying and practicing yoga, Sri Dharma Mittra developed Dharma Yoga to share his acquired wisdom with others.

Dharma Yoga is a comprehensive, classical yoga practice taught by a master yogi from India, drawing on his life experience and on the ancient, sacred texts. Dharma Yoga extends beyond the physical practice of the traditional yoga asanas to encompass a holistic lifestyle, including diet and purification practices, meditation and contemplation, ethics and philosophy, in order to attain spiritual freedom. The physical components of Dharma Yoga foster the development of strength and power within the body, offering protection from illnesses and diseases while improving one’s attitude and overall health.

Dharma Yoga classes are based on Dharma Mittra’s own experience of becoming a yogi and are therefore taught from a deep, integrative perspective. Instructors impart philosophical teachings to accompany the practice of yogic exercises and encourage students to keep a daily practice record. Classes range from very gentle to very advanced.
Dharma Yoga provides strength and power to the body, helping to defend against illness and disease.

item.title: Forrest Yoga
item.content:encoded: Forrest Yoga is a physically intense practice which focuses on carrying a transformative experience from the yoga mat into daily life. Classes revolve around accessing and strengthening the core of one's physical body and spiritual self. Forrest Yoga classes are challenging, pushing practitioners to test their personal limits. The benefits of Forrest Yoga include improved strength, posture, confidence, and attitude.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Ana Forrest created Forrest Yoga based on the notion that yoga is inherently healing and therapeutic, and when the practice is linked with positive language and encouragement, it can transform the way students experience life at large.

Forrest Yoga is a powerful and physically intense practice designed to create a transformative experience on the yoga mat that students can then carry back into daily life. Classes focus on developing core strength, both physically and spiritually. The challenging practice motivates students to push through mental and emotional blocks that limit them from becoming their best selves. The benefits of Forrest Yoga include improved strength, posture, confidence, and attitude.

While physically challenging, Forrest Yoga does not require great flexibility or strength of its students. Rather, it asks students to cultivate a willingness to learn how to respond to challenges, explore their limits, and experience honest emotions. Students develop an awareness of their own potential and are given a space in which to create new paradigms for approaching challenges, practicing patience, and developing self-compassion.
Forrest Yoga is a popular style that does not require strength or flexibility but a positive and willing mental attitude.

item.title: Freedom Style Yoga
item.content:encoded: Freedom Style Yoga is dedicated to helping practitioners grow into their own genuine expressions of yoga. Classes tend to be more advanced, but not overly challenging. The benefits of Freedom Yoga include increased confidence, positivity, focus, clarity and inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Erich Schiffmann is an experienced yoga master widely known for his award-winning video, Yoga Mind & Body, and his best-selling book, Moving Into Stillness. Eric developed Freedom Style Yoga as a way to facilitate an authentic, personalized yoga practice that develops trust in one's inner guidance.

Freedom Style Yoga is an advanced practice that is not inherently physically demanding, but is challenging in its practice of deep introspection and subtle self-awareness. Teachings include physical asanas and meditation.

Freedom Style Yoga is an instinctive, intuitive practice designed to help practitioners develop their own personal, authentic expressions of yoga.    The practice is centered around listening to one's own conscience and heart to tune into the wisdom of the universe and develop trust in one's inner guidance. The benefits of Freedom Yoga include increased confidence, positivity, focus, clarity, and inner peace.
nt of each student’s genuine expression of Yoga, using traditional methods but focusing on what works best for the student.

item.title: Heart Yoga
item.content:encoded: Heart Yoga is a deeply spiritual practice that combines the wisdom of yogis' teachings with spiritual traditions concerning concepts of "celestial light" and "sacred heart". Classes utilize basic yoga exercises, while simultaneously focusing on the mystical image of the Sacred Marriage of Immanence and Transcendence. The benefits of Heart Yoga include access to higher consciousness, enlightened living, improved clarity and inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Heart Yoga was developed by renowned spiritual writer Andrew Harvey and long-time yoga teacher Karuna Erickson with the intention of inspiring the yoga community to more actively utilize yoga as a tool to facilitate the divination of the physical body.

Heart Yoga is a yoga practice rooted in spirituality. At the core of the practice are contemplations on traditional yogic teachings and the concepts of "celestial light" and "sacred heart". The physical component of the practice--that is, the movement through poses--is designed to serve as a vehicle by which students may access higher consciousness. Heart Yoga strives to inspire those within the yoga community to become catalysts for spiritual development and self-actualization. Heart Yoga emphasizes a focus on the mystical image of the Sacred Marriage of Immanence and Transcendence. Heart Yoga promotes approaching the practice with joy, compassion, sacred peace, and sacred passion.

Heart Yoga classes combine ancient yoga teachings with mystical wisdom. Students can expect to practice traditional yoga postures and sequencing along with instruction regarding the teachings of yogic philosophy and various mystical traditions.
The Sacred Marriage of Yoga and Mysticism
Heart Yoga facilitates the divinization of the physical body with the aim of delivering the divine human.
Discover the benefits of Heart Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Hot Yoga
item.content:encoded: Hot Yoga refers to a practice of yoga under heated, and frequently humidified, conditions. It is most commonly associated with the Bikram and Power Vinyasa Flow styles of yoga. The aim of providing students with a warm and humid environment is to replicate the humidity and heat of South India, where most styles of yoga were originally developed. The benefits of Hot Yoga include increased balance, flexibility, muscle tone and detoxification.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Bikram style of Hot Yoga was introduced in the U.S. during the early 1970s by Bikram Choudhury, and is credited with popularizing the style of Hot Yoga.

During a Hot Yoga class, students can expect to sweat. The high temperature and humidity facilitates movement into certain poses, while also providing cardiovascular benefits. Depending on the style of yoga being praticed under such heated conditions, it can range in difficulty from moderately challenging to vigorous.

Hot Yoga is a vigorous, heart-pumping class performed under humid and hot conditions. It is most commonly associated with the Bikram and Power Vinyasa Flow styles of yoga. The heated room serves as an aid with increasing flexibility, allowing students to access deeper bends and twists. The heat also facilitates detoxification through sweat. Hot Yoga was designed to replicate the humidity and heat of South India, where most styles of yoga were developed.
Hot Yoga is practiced under hot and humid conditions (such as those of South India, where Yoga was originally developed), which serve to increase flexibility in poses.

item.title: Hridaya Yoga Sutra
item.content:encoded: Hridaya Yoga Sutra focuses on momentum, effort, and energy to support internal conditions needed for awakening the Spiritual Heart. This practice helps practitioners find peace and happiness in every moment of existence. The benefits of Hridaya Yoga Sutra are inner peace, quietness of mind, access to higher consciousness, enlightened living, and the unlocking of inner power.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Ramana Maharshi developed Hridaya Yoga Sutra to help students experience the essence of their Spiritual Hearts and overcome personal attachments, sentimentalism, and anxiety to allow for freer expression and exploration of oneself.

Hridaya Yoga Sutra incorporates aspects of Hatha Yoga, meditation, and sacred teachings with the aim of awakening the practitioner's Spiritual Heart. Classes also focus on techniques for silencing the mind and gaining the capacity for concentration.

Hridaya Yoga Sutra is a spiritually-oriented yoga practice which draws on the teachings of Christianity, Buddhism, and Taoism as well as yogic principles from the Sutras, Shaivism, Tantra and more. The aim of Hridaya Yoga Sutra is to live in the Supreme Reality, experiencing the Divine. The practice focuses on harnessing momentum, effort, and energy to create optimal internal conditions for awakening the Spiritual Heart. Regular practice of Hridaya Yoga Sutra helps participants learn how to enjoy every moment of existence with peace and happiness.

p>Hridaya Yoga Sutra draws from Christianity, Buddhism, and Taoism to help participants enjoy with peace every moment of existence, while focusing on Hatha and meditation to reveal the Spiritual Heart.

item.title: Inner Power® Yoga
item.content:encoded: Inner Power Yoga is a dynamic practice fusing playful, energetic sequences and authentic yoga philosophy with therapeutic physical alignment. Inner Power classes emphasize attention to the vibration of universal energy which manifests as authentic movement in the body. The benefits of Inner Power Yoga include connection to higher consciousness, enlightened living, inner peace and healing from trauma.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: R.R. Shakti developed Inner Power Yoga in 2001. Drawing on ancient yogic philosophy and modern yoga theory, Inner Power Yoga combines dynamic, flowing sequences with therapeutic alignment principles and an emphasis on tuning in to the flow of universal energy as it is expressed in the authentic movement of the body.

During an Inner Power Yoga class, you can expect a strong focus on the creative vibration of collective energy as it manifests in the movement of the body. The philosophy of Inner Power Yoga emphasizes the magnificence of our true nature and our interconnectedness to all things.

Inner Power Yoga is a dynamic practice designed to address all aspects of body, mind, and spirit.  The aim of Inner Power Yoga is to awaken the Inner Mind, or universal consciousness, which exists beneath the chatter of the personal mind's anxieties and desires. The practice fuses high-energy, flowing sequences with therapeutic bodily alignment and authentic yogic philosophy. Attention is placed on the vibration of universal energy, which manifests as authentic movement in the body.

Inner Power Yoga uses fun and entertaining sequences combined with Yoga philosophy to inspire the student and bring attention to the vibration of the collective energy and the interconnectedness of all things.

item.title: InSpirit® Yoga
item.content:encoded: InSpirit Yoga combines the teachings of Kripalu, Iyengar and Anusara Yoga in one environment, enlivening and encouraging students to explore the many dimensions of themselves on the mat. Classes are taught from a place of deep wisdom, utilizing alignment-based methods that are sound and safe for the body. The benefits of InSpirit Yoga include improved posture, balance, flexibility, energy and strength.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: InSpirit Yoga was developed by Suzie Hurley, an advanced yoga teacher with overs 35 years of meditation and yoga experience. InSpirit Yoga draws on Kripalu, Iyengar, and Anusara Yoga styles with an emphasis on sound alignment principles for a safe, therapeutic practice.

InSpirit Yoga is taught by Suzie Hurley, an advanced yoga teacher with over 35 years of yoga and meditation experience. Suzie teaches from a place of wisdom, joy, and practicality, creating a safe space for students to experience personal growth through their practice. Students can expect precise, knowledgeable guidance within a supportive, authentic atmosphere.

InSpirit Yoga draws on elements of Kripalu, Iyengar, and Anusara Yoga styles with a special emphasis on precise principles of alignment to ensure a safe and therapeutic practice. InSpirit Yoga is intended to empower students and encourage them to explore the many dimensions of themselves on the mat. The benefits of InSpirit Yoga include improved posture, balance, flexibility, energy and strength.
Inspirit Yoga uses a variety of Yoga styles, such as Kripalu, Iyengar, and Anusara, to encourage and motivate students through fun and authentic postures and meditations.

item.title: Integral Yoga
item.content:encoded: Integral Yoga was created to help fuse yogic teachings into everyday situations. Integral Yoga's mission is to promote greater tolerance and peace around the world by using yoga as a medium. Integral Yoga is based on the yogic values of a peaceful mind, a useful life, and an easeful body. The benefits of Integral Yoga are improved self-expression, inner peace, mental clarity, and connection to spirituality.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Integral Yoga was created in 1966 by Reverend Sri Swami Satchidananda to guide younger generations in the ancient yogic philosophies and their application to daily life. Integral Yoga promotes an easeful body, peaceful mind, and useful life.

An Integral Yoga class will incorporate an asana practice (poses) with breathing exercises, relaxation, silent meditation, and sound vibrations (chanting or mantra). The practice is designed to refine all aspects of body, mind, and spirit.

Integral Yoga was created to help bring yoga's ancient teachings for living a balanced life into the modern world.  Integral Yoga is a comprehensive practice involving all six traditional branches of yoga: physical asanas, meditation, devotion to the Divine, selfless service, sacred knowledge, and healing sound vibration. The practice of Integral Yoga is designed not only to create a more easeful body and settled mind, but to promote greater tolerance and peace within everyday relationships and work.
Integral Yoga uses meditation and postures combined with philosophy to insert Yoga’s teachings into everyday life, promoting a greater tolerance and peace in practitioners and the world around.

item.title: Integrative Yoga Therapy
item.content:encoded: Integrative Yoga Therapy is a yoga teacher training program created for mainstream medical wellness facilities, including rehabilitation centers and hospitals. The practice focuses on the patient’s emotional, spiritual, and physical well-being in order to heal from injury, trauma, disease, and chronic conditions. The benefits of Integrative Yoga are improved health and vitality, enhanced focus, and the cultivation of a positive spirit and self-esteem.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Integrative Yoga Therapy was created by Joseph Le Page in 1993 to develop a yoga program tailored to mainstream wellness and medical settings, specifically rehabilitation centers and hospitals. In an effort to enhance Western medicine, Integrative Yoga Therapy caters primarily to those recovering from injury and illness who are looking for a holistic, comprehensive approach to healing.

Integrative Yoga Therapy offers a well-rounded approach to healing on a physical, psychological and spiritual level.  Integrative Yoga Therapy sessions may include physical therapy, speech therapy or psychological therapy along with yoga, meditation and breathing exercises. Sessions will be personalized for the needs of the patient.

Integrative Yoga Therapy was created for use within mainstream and medical wellness facilities, such as rehabilitation centers and hospitals, to assist patients recovering from illness and injury. Integrative Yoga Therapy is grounded in a holistic philosophy which suggests that healing must occur within all levels of the patient's being--emotional, spiritual, and physical--in order to be successful.
Integrative Yoga Therapy promotes medical wellness in a safe environment by healing through bonds with the deepest parts of a person: the emotional, spiritual, and physical.

item.title: ISHTA Yoga
item.content:encoded: The Integrated Science of Hatha, Tantra and Ayurveda (ISHTA), focuses on balancing the human body to develop a stable and strong platform for spiritual growth. ISHTA Yoga classes focus on calming the mind and re-centering the spirit. The benefits of ISHTA Yoga include building confidence, positivity, clarity of mind, focus, and inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: ISHTA was created in South Africa during the 1960s by renowned yoga master Alan Finger, alongside his father, Kavi Yogiraj Mani Finger, a disciple of Swami Venkatesananda and Paramahansa Yogananda.

A typical  ISHTA class will take students through flowing sequences of postures reminiscent of the Ashtanga and Iyengar traditions, including standing poses, balancing poses, and classical sun salutations. Students are encouraged to learn to listen to their bodies to properly align their postures and link their movements to their breath. Classes will also involve meditation techniques and encourage self-awareness and self-acceptance.

ISHTA is an acronym for Integrated Science of Hatha, Tantra and Ayurveda.  Hatha refers to physical yoga postures, Tantra refers to meditative practices, and Ayurveda is an ancient system for holistic health. These three yogic elements combine to create a healthy, balanced body and mind as a platform for spiritual growth. The word Ishta in Sanskrit also means "individual". ISHTA yoga promotes developing a personalized practice to addresses one's individual needs and discover one's own path.

The Integrated Science of Hatha, Tantra, and Ayurveda (ISHTA) uses Vinyasa Yoga sequences emphasizing alignment, pranayama, and meditation to improve energy and develop a strong platform for spiritual growth.
Discover the benefits of ISHTA Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Iyengar Yoga
item.content:encoded: Iyengar Yoga focuses on the alignment of the physical body. Iyengar Yoga is centered around standing postures which are held for an elongated period of time. This ensures that the teacher and practitioner can pay distinct attention to skeletal and muscular alignment. Classes incorporate various props such as chairs, belts, blankets and blocks. The benefits of Iyengar Yoga include improved posture, energy awareness, strength and flexibility.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Iyengar method was developed in Pune, India by the world-renowned yoga master B.K.S. Iyengar, one of the pioneers responsible for first bringing yoga to the West.  B.K.S. Iyengar revolutionized yoga practice by the use of props to make yoga more widely and safely achievable.  At 80 years old, B.K.S. lyengar continues to instruct students from all over the world.

lyengar yoga classes are accessible to students of all levels of experience, flexibility, strength, and balance.  Students can expect to use a variety of props in order to achieve poses with proper alignment, ensuring that the practice is safe and beneficial for the body. Poses are slow and deep, allowing the student to relax into each position and let go of resistance.

Iyengar Yoga was developed to make classical yoga poses accessible to everyone by modifying the poses to suit the needs of the individual. Poses are held for long periods of time to allow the students and teacher to pay distinct attention to skeletal and muscular alignment. Iyengar Yoga utilizes various props such as chairs, belts, blankets, and blocks to facilitate deeper, longer holds and to accommodate the student's special needs. The practice is therapeutic for the body and helps lead the mind toward deeper peace.
In Iyengar Yoga, poses tend to be standing and are held longer than in other styles of Yoga, emphasizing the attention to skeletal and muscular alignment.

item.title: Jivamukti Yoga
item.content:encoded: Jivamukti Yoga is based on the ideal of liberation while living. A popular practice among celebrities, Jivamukti focuses on ethical, spiritual and physical aspects of yoga together. The physical embodiment of Jivamukti Yoga is marked by a hybrid of Vinyasa/Power styles with vigorous Hatha Yoga poses. The benefits of Jivamukti Yoga include improved self-expression, focus, mental clarity, flexibility, muscle tone, and balance.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Jivamukti Yoga was developed by David Life and Sharon Gannon, who founded The Jivamukti Yoga School in New York in 1984. Their method is credited with reviving yoga's ancient holistic philosophies and presenting them in an accessible, modern way. Jivamukti Yoga has become popular with many celebrities.

Jivamukti Yoga classes involve flowing vinyasa yoga sequences along with breathwork, meditation, chanting, and spiritual teachings. Music often plays an important role as a tool for developing one's capacity for deep listening, considered one of the paths to spiritual awakening. Jivamukti Yoga practice is designed to develop all aspects of one's being and to apply to all aspects of one's lifestyle.

Jivamukti Yoga is a physical, ethical, and spiritual practice based on a philosophy of Oneness and compassion for all beings. Jivamukti Yoga provides a framework for a holistic, spiritual lifestyle which includes devotion, scripture, music, non-harming, and meditation along with physical yoga asana practice. The physical practice of Jivamukti Yoga consists of vigorous Vinyasa-based flow sequences, usually to the accompaniment of music.

Jivamukti Yoga is an ethical, spiritual and physical practice combining Vinyasa styles with vigorous Hatha Yoga; it also focuses strongly on environmentalism, animal rights, veganism, and social activism.

item.title: Kali Natha Yoga
item.content:encoded: The transformational Kali Natha Yoga unites and embraces both Western and Eastern philosophies. Kali Natha Yoga is extremely spiritual, enabling the practitioner to feel oneness and experience a state of lasting happiness. Classes integrate prayer and worship in order to connect all aspects of life to a sense of the divine. The benefits of Kali Natha Yoga are the experience of divine wisdom, enlightened living, and connection to higher consciousness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Kali Natha Yoga was founded by Ma Jaya, who describes the practice as a moving worship and prayer.

Kali Natha Yoga is a deeply spiritual practice described as "moving prayer." Drawing on both Western and Eastern philosophies, it strives to release blocks and limitations in the body, mind and spirit to allow the practitioner to experience oneness. Kali Natha Yoga's name is derived from the all-embracing Mother Kali, a Hindu goddess associated with empowerment, and the ancient Nathas or Yogis from Lord Shiva’s lineage. This balance of the feminine and masculine energies creates a balanced, comprehensive practice which facilitates a deep sense of self-awareness.

A Kali Natha Yoga class utilizes mantra (chanting), pranayama (breathwork) and mudra (flowing gestures), striving to open up every chakra and weave together the body, soul and mind. Classes are open to students of all levels of experience or fitness; there are no beginning to advanced "levels."
Kali Natha Yoga is an extremely spiritual, transformational practice uniting Eastern and Western philosophies through use of Mantra, pranayama and mudra.

item.title: Karma Yoga
item.content:encoded: Karma Yoga is based on teachings from the Bhagavad Gita, a key philosophical and spiritual text from Hinduism. Karma Yoga focuses on the road to obtaining perfection by way of selfless service and eliminating attachment to benefits derived from actions. The benefits of Karma Yoga include enlightened living, connection to higher consciousness, a stronger sense of community, inner peace, quietness of mind, and improved self-expression

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The teachings of Karma Yoga are derived from the Bhagavad Gita, a sacred Hindu scripture that originated during Lord Krishna’s dynasty. A central focus of the Bhagavad Gita is the concept of "right action", or action in accord with Divine Will.  The scripture teaches that surrendering attachment to the outcome of one's actions removes the ego from the equation and allows one to function as an instrument of Natural Law.

During a Karma Yoga class, poses are held for longer periods, allowing students to stay present in the moment and observe without judgment what thoughts and feelings arise. Students are encouraged to challenge themselves and explore their limitations while releasing their desire to "achieve."  Teachers frequently integrate Karma Yoga practice with acts of service, such as opportunities to volunteer or raise money for charity.

Karma Yoga is the path to self-realization through selfless "right action."  The purpose of Karma Yoga is to learn to surrender the ego's attachment to the outcome of one's actions in order to function as an instrument of divine will.  What is important in Karma Yoga is not the action itself, but the state of mind from which that action is performed. The practice of Karma Yoga may involve physical postures, meditation, and/or acts of service, all performed with sincere intention but without expectation regarding the outcome.
Karma Yoga is based on the teaching from the Bhagavad Gita and focuses on the road to perfection through selfless service.
Discover the benefits of Karma Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Kripalu Yoga
item.content:encoded: Kripalu Yoga is a series of movements grouped in three stages of practice. The stages are breath, alignment, and consciousness. Class technique involves holding postures to deepen concentration and focus thoughts to perform movements and postures that release mental and physical tensions. The benefits of Kripalu Yoga include improved strength, focus, clarity, flexibility and inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Kripalu Yoga classes tend to be physically involved and may range from moderately challenging to advanced. A combination of flowing postures, breathing instruction, and spiritual instruction are weaved together in a Kripalu Yoga class. Students can expect to feel engaged and energized during class and peacefully relaxed at its finish.

Kripalu Yoga was developed at The Kripalu Center for Yoga and Health, a nonprofit retreat center in the Berkshire Mountains of Western Massachusetts that has been delivering yoga and wellness retreats to the community since 1983.

Kripalu Yoga practice is based on the interplay of body, mind, and energy. The philosophy behind Kripalu is that wellness depends on the unobstructed flow of subtle energy known as "prana" or life-force. Negative thoughts and emotions are believed to obstruct the flow of prana and manifest in physical pain and illness. Kripalu Yoga practice involves a dynamic, flowing series of postures with focused breathing in order to cultivate a healthy flow of prana. Students are encouraged to observe any thoughts and feelings that arise with non-judgment and acceptance, cultivating self-awareness and quietness of mind.
Discover the benefits of Kripalu Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Kriya
item.content:encoded: Kriya Yoga is an ancient yoga tradition, which was revitalized during modern times. The style was introduced to the United States in 1920 and popularized through Paramahansa Yogananda’s autobiography, "Autobiography of a Yogi". Kriya Yoga contains various levels of pranayama-derived techniques (involving work with the breath), which aim to enhance and encourage spiritual development. The benefits of Kriya Yoga include improved focus, clarity, enlightenment, and experience of divine wisdom.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Kriya Yoga was revived by Mahavatar Babaji and his disciple Lahiri Mahasaya around the year1861. It was later popularized by Paramahansa Yogananda, who introduced Kriya Yoga to the United States in 1920.

During a Kriya Yoga class, student will learn to direct their energy to revolve either downward or upward around six spinal centers. This practice is aimed at focusing the mind, body, and spirit toward a deeper understanding of oneself and one's energetic interconnectedness to the universe as a whole.

Kriya Yoga is an ancient yoga tradition revitalized during modern times. It was introduced to the United States in 1920 and popularized through the book Autobiography of a Yogi, by Paramahansa Yogananda. It consists of various levels of pranayama-derived techniques (which link breath to movement), with the intention of accelerating spiritual development and creating a deep state of harmony. Kriya Yoga directs energy around six spinal centers, which relate to the 12 signs of the zodiac.
The Kriya Yoga Path of Meditation

Kriya Yoga is composed of several pranayama techniques, serving to speed up spiritual development and create a deep state of harmony; it focuses specifically on the 6 spinal centers, corresponding with the 12 signs of the zodiac.

item.title: Kula Flow Yoga
item.content:encoded: Kula Flow Yoga is a Vinyasa (flowing) style of yoga which emphasizes alignment and creativity. The practice utilizes both standing and seated postures, which are guided by steady breath. Physical postures function to fortify the outer, physical body; steady breath promotes connection to the "inner body" and its relationship to the physical. Kula Flow Yoga is a challenging and more advanced style of yoga. The benefits of Kula Flow Yoga include physical strengthening and improved stamina, rejuvenation, and joyfulness of spirit.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Kula Flow Yoga was developed by Schuyler Grant, who is the director of Project Kula Yoga in New York City. She developed Kula Flow to incorporate bandha with a combination of asanas (poses) and breath.

Kula Flow’s classes are available for students of all levels; however, they do tend to be more physically rigorous. Classes are comprised mainly of vigorous sun salutations, followed by various standing and balancing postures and bandha (engaging deep, inner musculature). Classes are typically practiced in this specific order to develop strength and flexibility while also promoting calmness and peace of mind.

Kula Flow Yoga is a Vinyasa (flowing) style which emphasizes alignment and creativity. Kula Flow Yoga utilizes both standing and seated postures guided by steady breath; because deep and steady breath feeds the physical body, emphasis is often placed on the depth of breathing over maximal expression of a posture. Kula Flow Yoga is a physically demanding practice which supports physical strengthening, improved flexibility, calmness of mind, and happiness of spirit. While physically difficult, Kula Flow Yoga is accessible to many levels in that it encourages testing and understanding one's own personal limits, whatever they might be.
Inner Light Center for Yoga & Meditation
Kula Flow strengthens the inner and outer body by steady breathing in seated and standing postures with an emphasis on alignment and creativity.

item.title: Kundalini Yoga
item.content:encoded: Kundalini literally means “the curl of the lock of hair of the beloved”. Kundalini Yoga is regarded as the broadest of the various yoga traditions because it fuses mantra, meditation, breathing techniques and physical exercise. The benefits of Kundalini Yoga include increased muscle tone, improved balance and flexibility, connection to higher consciousness, and clarity of mind.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Kundalini literally means "the curl of the lock of hair of the beloved". It is regarded as the broadest of the various yoga traditions: it fuses mantra (chanting), meditation, breathing techniques and physical exercise. A deeply spiritual and ritualistic embodiment of yoga practice, Kundalini Yoga incorporates values from the 8 Limbs of Yoga together into one practice. It strives to connect universal and individual consciousness, to create true "yoga," which means "union".

A Kundalini Yoga class will be physically challenging and spiritually fulfilling, enabling practitioners to explore the connection between their individual consciousness and that of the universe. Classes frequently contain significant periods devoted to chanting and divine prayer.

Kundalini Yoga dates back further than the 5th century B.C. Kundalini Yoga originated as a sacred technology and science which was passed on orally from master to disciple for many generations. In modern times, Yogi Bhajan has popularized the study of Kundalini Yoga.

item.title: LifeForce® Yoga
item.content:encoded: LifeForce Yoga is designed to help students access and retrain the psychoemotional aspects of themselves. LifeForce Yoga combines ancient Tantric and Classical practices with scientific understandings of the brain, mind, and behavior. The method adapts to each student, ensuring that the individual moves into a balanced mental, physical and emotional state of self-awareness. The benefits of LifeForce Yoga include increased inner peace, joy, relaxation, self-expression and positivity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: LifeForce Yoga classes incorporate aspects of meditation, Tantra and classical yoga postures to foster the establishment of a balanced, calm, nonreactive mind.
LifeForce Yoga was developed by Amy Weintraub as a therapeutic tool specifically targeted toward improving mental health.

Originally designed as a therapeutic tool for those suffering from depression, anxiety, and psychological and emotional trauma, LifeForce Yoga serves as a powerful healing practice for its students. By combining ancient Tantric and Classical practices with scientific understandings of the brain, mind, and behavior, LifeForce Yoga embodies a true hybridization of Eastern and Western philosophies. It encourages participants to develop compassion for themselves, and to embrace who they are. The LifeForce method is adaptable to each student, ensuring that the individual moves into a balanced mental, physical and emotional state of self-awareness and equanimity.
LifeForce Yoga combines ancient Tantric and classical practices with modern science, emphasizing compassion, balance, and self-awareness.

item.title: Lilias Style Yoga
item.content:encoded: Lilias Style Yoga is a gentle style of yoga, based primarily on the yogic experiences of its founder, Lilias Folan. Lilias Style Yoga focuses on breathing and alignment while carefully performing each exercise. The aim of this is to create a deep understanding of purpose and intention. The benefits of Lilias Yoga include improved balance, flexibility, focus, posture, energy awareness, and inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Lilias Folan, founder of Lilias Style Yoga, considers herself a life-long spiritual seeker. She developed her unique style of yoga as a way to practice truly connecting with one's inner self.

Lilias Style Yoga is a gentle style of yoga which draws on several different yoga traditions and on the personal experiences of its founder, Lilias Folan. Lilias Style Yoga focuses on breathing and alignment while putting careful attention on each pose. The poses are often explained and expounded upon extensively, both to prevent injury and to clarify the purpose and intention of each pose. The practice of Lilias Style Yoga improves flexibility and energy by accessing every major joint and muscle in the body, while cultivating deep self-awareness through focused intention.

During Lilias Style classes, students can expect to gently engage in various postures while paying attention to breath and alignment. Instructors spend much time describing the postures in detail and making careful adjustments. The benefits of Lilias Yoga include improved balance, flexibility, focus, posture, energy awareness, and inner peace.
Lilias Style Yoga is a gentle style focusing on breathing, alignment, and pulling apart the poses to create a more fulfilling and complete practice.

item.title: Manifestation Yoga
item.content:encoded: Manifestation Yoga is specifically designed to revitalize practitioners’ energies, and learn to accept and welcome change in their lives. Classes are physically engaging, but are overlain with a relaxed attitude, and humor is welcomed. If a practitioner falls during a pose, laughter is expected by the falling yogi and his or her neighbors. The benefits of Manifestation Yoga include increased joy, focus, clarity, flexibility and rejuvenation.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Manifestation Yoga was created by Jennifer Pastiloff, whose aim was to develop a style of yoga that is inspirational, practical, and transformative.

Manifestation Yoga is designed to promote meaningful change in practitioners' lives both on an off the yoga mat. The practice of Manifestation Yoga focuses on transforming one's reactions in order to manifest the life one truly desires. Students are encouraged to embrace the challenge of the yoga poses with full commitment while maintaining a light, good-humored attitude. By testing their physical limits and confronting difficulties with non-attachment, students transform their attitudes toward life's challenges.

Manifestation Yoga classes promote an atmosphere of playfulness, laughter, and non-reactivity. Students are encouraged to approach their practice with deep engagement and yet with personal detachment. The practice is challenging, uplifting and empowering.
Manifestation Yoga is a relaxing, humbling technique that emphasizes the importance of laughter and light-heartedness -- even in serious life breakthroughs.

item.title: Maya Yoga
item.content:encoded: Maya Yoga is a system of yoga dedicated to serving the needs of the unique individual. Classes focus on tailoring a specific system of yoga postures for each practitioner. The aim of a custom-tailored practice is to help foster a sense of inner knowing within students. The benefits of Maya Yoga are improved clarity, focus, balance, muscle tone and connection to inner awareness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Maya Yoga was developed by renowned modern yogis Nicki Doane and Eddie Modestini with the intention of offering a creative and dynamic style of yoga that takes into account human beings' unique variability. Maya Yoga draws on the teachings of Sri K. Pattabhi Jois and B.K.S. Iyengar, viewing yoga as both a physical practice and a spiritual path.

Maya Yoga is a system of yoga dedicated to serving the needs of the individual. Maya Yoga philosophy holds that yoga represents the spirit in action, and that each pose is a unique expression of one's physical and spiritual being. The practice of Maya Yoga involves a dynamic form of flowing vinyasa yoga poses with focus on structural alignment and conscious breathing. The intention of the practice is to learn to be truly present in the moment and to experience the connection between Spirit and oneself.

During a Maya Yoga class, students can expect a dynamic and physically fulfilling practice that is tailored to their personal needs. The instructors offer physical adjustments and philosophical insights while encouraging students to listen to their own inner guidance. Students focus on breath and alignment as a means of keeping their attention in the present moment.

Maya Yoga serves the needs of the individual, adhering to the belief that Yoga is spirit in action, and developing the strong connection between spirit and body through a dynamic and fulfilling practice.

item.title: Meditation
item.content:encoded: Meditation refers to the practice of training the mind to seamlessly access and transition through various levels of consciousness. There are many different meditation techniques, and most styles of yoga participate in meditation in some form or another. The benefits of meditation are improved focus, clarity, wisdom, confidence, positivity, inner peace, and a connection to higher consciousness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Meditation is an ancient practice dating back thousands of years. There are many different kinds of meditation, from those rooted in various spiritual traditions to modern secular practices utilized for stress reduction.

During a Meditation class, students will learn techniques to train their attention in a particular direction, whether it is focusing on a particular subject, witnessing their own thoughts and feelings, or transcending the world of thoughts and experiencing pure awareness. Various techniques might use a repeated mantra or sound, focused breathing exercises, visualizations, or contemplation of scriptural passages.

Meditation is a broad term that refers to a variety of practices designed to develop one's awareness and unfold the potential of the mind. Depending on the particular tradition or style of meditation, the goal may be mental, physical, psychological, spiritual, or all of the above. Different meditation practices may involve developing mental discipline and focus, practicing non-attachment to one's emotional reactions, cultivating qualities of compassion or devotion, or experiencing higher states of consciousness and spiritual oneness. Most meditation practices involve quieting or clarifying one's thoughts, which has a calming effect on the mind, body, and psyche.
Meditation Yoga teaches techniques that help to calm the mind and make accessible a higher level of conscious awareness.
Discover the benefits of Meditation and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Meditation in Movement
item.content:encoded: Meditation in Movement Style Yoga is a physically healing system that simultaneously focuses on a practitioner's ability to clear the mind and experience oneness while performing poses. The classes consist of 10 movements that are performed while listening to relaxing music and searching for internal peace. The benefits of Meditation in Movement Style Yoga are increased focus, clarity, inner peace, confidence, joy and rejuvenation.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Lanita Varshell developed Meditation in Movement to address her own issues with chronic pain.

Meditation in Movement Style Yoga (MIMSY) is a gentle, therapeutic form of yoga that incorporates mindfulness meditation with deep, long postural holds. The physical practice of Meditation in Movement aims to address deep tensions within the spine and hips, using seated and reclined postures to bring maximal openness and healing energy to these areas. The practice is deeply relaxing, allowing the mind to settle and the awareness to expand.

Meditation in Movement classes focus on restorative poses that aid in opening the hips and healing the spine. A series of ten poses is practiced to the accompaniment of relaxing music. Long, deep posture holds access the innermost layers of muscles, joints, and fascia and allow the mind to become settled and clear.
Pilgrimage of the Heart of Yoga
Meditation in Movement aims to relieve stress and pressures on the back and spine, healing through achievable floor poses that open the hips.

item.title: MogaDao Yoga
item.content:encoded: MogaDao Yoga is an innovative practice that combines Hatha Yoga with classical yoga asanas (poses). Classes are designed for the practitioner to experience a well-rounded blend of yoga, qigong (life-force), meditation and Daoist philosophy. The benefits of MogaDao Yoga include improved inner-peace, quietness of mind, positivity, confidence, enlightenment, self expression, and connection to higher consciousness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: MogaDao Yoga was developed by Daniel Villasenor to infuse his yoga practice with his deep knowledge of Daoist traditions.

MogaDao Yoga classes are organized around the five elements of traditional Chinese medicine: Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal, Water. Students practice a wide range of classical yoga asanas hybridized with motions derived from qigong, resulting in a dynamic, flowing, and meditative practice.

MogaDao Yoga is an innovative yoga system which fuses classical Ashtanga and Iyengar yoga with a Daoist philosophical and spiritual paradigm. The practice of MogaDao involves performing either slow Hatha or dynamic Vinyasa yoga poses while incorporating an awareness of qi, or subtle energy, as practiced in traditional qigong. MogaDao Yoga seeks to create a state of inner harmony and balance consistent with the 5 Element Theory that underlies Traditional Chinese Medicine.
MogaDao Yoga is based off of Hatha and takes a specific elemental theme as a focal point in each class, making use of Asanas to create a well-thought-out practice.

item.title: Naam Yoga
item.content:encoded: Naam Yoga is a unique synthesis of traditional yoga practices with teachings from the Universal Kabbalah. Recognized by Yoga Alliance as a Yoga Therapy, Naam Yoga is designed to promote physical, mental and spiritual health and rehabilitation through conscious movement, breathwork, and mantra. The practice of Naam Yoga helps to balance the glandular, digestive and nervous systems, strengthen the immune system, and reduce stress, providing relief from chronic pain, anxiety and depression.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Naam yoga was developed by Dr. Joseph Michael Levry, a renowned yogi, mystic, writer, and lecturer with over thirty years of teaching and research experience. Naam yoga was devised as a way to synthesize the practice of yoga with the spiritual teachings of the Kabbalah.

Naam Yoga is a unique synthesis of traditional yoga practices with teachings from the Universal Kabbalah. Recognized by Yoga Alliance as a Yoga Therapy, Naam Yoga is designed to unlock the self-healing potential of the mind and body through conscious movement, breathwork, and mantra. The practice of Naam Yoga helps to balance the glandular, digestive and nervous systems, strengthen the immune system, and reduce stress, providing relief from chronic pain, anxiety and depression.

Naam Yoga classes work with movement, sound, and breath to restore the flow of vital energy through the body. A range of Naam yoga classes are available, from gentle restorative classes to dynamic vinyasa classes. Some classes involve meditation, chanting, visualization, or prayer.
Naam Yoga uses hand symbols, breathing, and the wisdom of nature to reduce stress and open consciousness.

item.title: OM Yoga
item.content:encoded: OM Yoga strives to bring practitioners closer to the realization of oneness with the “all”, or universal. Classes utilize the chanting of “om” in order to unlock energy from within the body and enable the participant to experience the light of the universe. The benefits of OM Yoga are improved mental clarity, enhanced focus, access to higher consciousness, positivity and a sense of inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: During an OM Yoga class, students engage in medium-paced Vinyasa sequences with a strong focuse on alignment. The chanting of the word "om" serves as a focal point throughout the class, providing students with a therapeutic physical vibration that resonates with the sacred energy of the universe. Students can expect to encounter Tibetan Buddhist concepts such as compassion and mindfulness.
Cyndi Lee, founder and developer of OM Yoga and the OM Center in New York City, was inspired by her extensive practice of yoga and studies of Tibetan Buddhism.

Based on the ancient traditions of yoga as well as Tibetan Buddhism, OM Yoga is a physical and spiritual practice that strives to fuse compassion and mindfulness into all aspects of life. “Om” is said to be the primordial sound that facilitated creation, and repeating this mantra is intended to enliven that universal creative energy within one's own awareness. The practice of OM Yoga combines alignment-based vinyasa yoga asanas with Tibetan Buddhist style meditation and chanting.
OM Yoga strives to cultivate stability, clarity and strength through use of the word “Om”, believed to be the sound present when the universe began.
Discover the benefits of OM Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: ParaYoga®
item.content:encoded: ParaYoga is a yoga style created with principles taken from modern life as well as ancient texts. Classes focus on reaching one's overall potential by performing challenging exercises that apply to body, mind and spirit. The benefits of ParaYoga are improved balance, flexibility, muscle tone, energy awareness, peace and enlightenment.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: ParaYoga was developed by Rod Stryker in 1995, following his experiences as a student of Pandit Rajmani Tigunait and Kavi Yogiraj.

ParaYoga classes combine dynamic Vinyasa Krama sequences with a variety of other practices that involve body, breath and mind, ranging from meditation, chanting and visualization to pranayama (breath work), bandhas (accessing internal muscles) and mudras (flowing gestures). Emphasis is placed on the energetics in each of these practices, in accord with Tantric philosophy. Students can expect to leave class feeling re-enlivened in body, mind, and spirit.

ParaYoga draws on the most ancient and comprehensive yoga traditions and presents them in a contemporary context. The purpose of ParaYoga is to master one's life by mastering one's essential life-force or energy. According to classical Tantric teachings, the energy forces within the body mirror those in the outer universe, and refining and developing these forces within helps to bring success and fulfillment in the world as well. ParaYoga practice utilizes hatha yoga asanas, breathwork, meditation, and a variety of other ancient yogic practices in order to develop and refine one's life-force.
ParaYoga is rooted both in ancient texts and modern life, aiming to manifest worldly spiritual success, a refinement of prana and an increase in self-awareness.
Discover the benefits of ParaYoga® and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Phoenix Rising
item.content:encoded: Phoenix Rising Yoga Therapy fuses modern psychological practices with classic yoga techniques. The combination of conversing over negative thoughts and experiences while performing yoga exercises is meant to be the ultimate therapy for releasing unwanted energy and restoring positivity. The benefits of Phoenix Rising Yoga Therapy include improved self-expression, joy, inner peace, confidence and positivity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Phoenix Rising Yoga Therapy was created during the mid 1980s by Michael Lee, drawing on his studies of humanistic psychology and yoga therapy. Phoenix Rising Yoga Therapy utilizes the relationship between the physical and emotional self to help heal the body, mind, and spirit.

Phoenix Rising Yoga Therapy is a unique one-on-one practice that fuses elements of modern mind-body psychology and therapy with classical yoga poses. Its aim is to bring about a release of both emotional blockages and physical tensions through the use of practitioner-assisted yoga postures, guided breathing, and non-directive dialogue. The practice of Phoenix Rising Yoga Therapy facilitates a connection between the emotional and physical self, and aids in personal growth by encouraging the release of negative holding patterns in mind, spirit and body.

During a Phoenix Rising Yoga Therapy session, the client is gently guided through various yoga postures with sensitive hands-on assistance. Through focused breathing and an open-ended dialogue process, the client places awareness on thoughts and feelings that emerge in the present moment, and verbalizes them within a safe and loving space. This physical and psychological process allows the client to release unprocessed experiences, traumas, and out-dated beliefs and thought patterns.
Phoenix Rising Yoga Therapy is a fusion of modern mind-body psychology and traditional Yoga, using breathing exercises and postures to promote personal growth and peace of mind.
Discover the benefits of Phoenix Rising and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Power Yoga
item.content:encoded: Power Yoga is aimed at providing a space in which practitioners can develop their highest level of physical fitness while maintaining the core principles of yogic philosophy and spirituality. The challenging classes focus on strength and flexibility; the physical manifestation is the centerpiece, and mediation and breathwork tend to have a smaller presence. The mental aspect of yoga is mostly an afterthought, although proponents suggest that mental clarity and peace naturally follow a physically demanding challenge. The benefits of Power Yoga include increased strength, flexibility, muscle tone and weight loss.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Power Yoga is a generic term for modern yoga styles which are derived from the tradition of Ashtanga Yoga, but do not adhere strictly to its specific series of movements or related practices such as chanting and meditation. Teachers such as Beryl Bender Birch, Bryan Kest, and Baron Baptiste are credited with popularizing Power Yoga in the Western world and its fitness scene. Power Yoga brought yoga into gyms, bringing yoga a new level of noteriety and popularity.

In a Power Yoga class, students engage in challenging and dynamic flowing postures, often practicing in a hot room. Power Yoga classes offer a safe and encouraging environment for students to explore their personal boundaries and learn to work with, not against, themselves.

Power Yoga is a vigorous, athletic style of Vinyasa yoga designed to foster the highest levels of vitality, freedom, and physical energy. The intense, flowing practice draws on the traditions of Ashtanga but does not follow a set series of postures. Power Yoga focuses on developing strength, flexibility and fitness while challenging one's physical and psychological limitations, thereby encouraging personal empowerment.
In Power Yoga, the aim is to create the highest possible levels of vitality, freedom, and energy by working naturally with yourself
Discover the benefits of Power Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
