item.title: Prana Flow Yoga
item.content:encoded: Prana Flow is a more active form of Vinyasa Yoga, and is generally described as energetic, fluid, and creative. The classes consist of sequences that incorporate aspects of moving meditation and fluid movements. The benefits of Prana Flow Yoga include improved strength, energy, positivity, focus, balance, flexibility, inner peace, mental clarity, and an unlocking of inner power.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Shiva Rea developed Prana Flow Yoga in 2005 after combining aspects of her backgrounds in yoga, dance, Indian martial arts, and Ayurveda.

Prana Flow is a fluid and creative form of Vinyasa Yoga, and is generally described as empowering and challenging. Its flowing movement sequences incorporate aspects of moving meditation and dance along with music, aiming to connect students to their breath and subtle energetics.
A Prana Flow class will begin with with chanting of "om", followed by continuous movement. The class is characterized by a fusion of moving meditation, yoga flow, dance, and music.
Prana Flow is an empowering and challenging form of Vinyasa Yoga using Om, meditation, and dance to help students connect movement and breath.

item.title: Pranava Yoga
item.content:encoded: Pranava Yoga relies on classic meditative rituals, such as the “om” meditation, to bring practitioners closer to an understanding of oneness and universality. Classes utilize the chanting of “om” in order to unlock energy and enable the participant to experience connection to the universe. The benefits of Pranava Yoga include enhanced mental clarity and focus, connection to higher consciousness, positivity, and peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Pranava Yoga was developed based on the belief that “aum” is the sound from which the universe was created. The discipline is based on the meditation described in the Bhagavad Gita, the Yoga Sutras of Patanjali, and the Upanishads.

During a Pranava Yoga class, students can expect an extensive practice of mantra, which constitutes repetition of the same verbal sounds with the aim of producing a specific psychological or physical effect in the one who repeats it.

Pranava Yoga (Om Yoga/Om Yoga Meditation) refers to classical meditation as described in the Bhagavad Gita, the Yoga Sutras of Patanjli and the Upanishads. It is a method of focusing on the hum of the mantra, "om" or "aum," which is repeated alongside the breath. "Aum" is believed to be the sound from which the universe was created, and Pranava Yoga strives to help practitioners establish a connection to creation and unity. Pranava Yoga teaches that once this union is understood, we become liberated from limitations and suffering.
Pranava Yoga refers to classical meditation and is based on the word “Aum”, the sound believed to be present when the universe was created.

item.title: Prenatal / Postnatal Yoga
item.content:encoded: Prenatal/Postnatal Yoga aims to help mothers prepare for labor, stay fit before and after pregnancy, and nourish their bodies as they undergo physiologic changes that accompany pregnancy and motherhood. Classes range from beginner to advanced levels while offering simple, effective, and safe exercises. The Prenatal/Postnatal Yoga philosophy endorses strengthening the body, unwinding areas of stress and tension, and promoting the overall health and vitality of both mother and child. The benefits of Prenatal/Postnatal Yoga include improved flexibility and strength, enhanced vitality, and a strengthened bond between mother and child.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: During a Prenatal/Postnatal Yoga class, students can expect to participate in comforting, nourishing, bond-strengthening postures in an encouraging and supportive environment.
Prenatal-Postnatal Yoga classes were developed to assist and nurture new mothers in strengthening and nourishing the body in preparation for a natural childbirth.

Prenatal/Postnatal Yoga classes offer simple, effective, and safe exercises which are designed to relax and strengthen a mother's changing body in preparation for mindful childbirth and parenting. Prenatal/Postnatal Yoga facilitates comfort, relaxation, and bonding between mother and baby.
Prenatal/Postnatal Yoga Classes are simple, safe exercises designed to relax and strengthen the changing body in preparation for conscious childbirth.

item.title: Purna™
item.content:encoded: Purna Yoga emphasizes uniting all aspects of life through stretching, meditation and relaxation. Classes are built on the principle of cautious alignment for the duration of each pose. The Purna style of yoga aims to deepen the practitioners' awareness and appreciation for their bodies. The benefits of Purna Yoga include improved balance, flexibility, strength, focus, clarity and inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Purna Yoga was developed by Mirra and Aadil Palkhivala, drawing on teachings from Sri Aurobindo and the Mother. It was designed to offer a comprehensive, integral approach to mind-body-spirit health.

Purna Yoga is a classically-rooted, holistic yoga style that aims to achieve yoga's original, highest goal: uniting the mind, body and spirit and with the universe. Through alignment-based yoga postures, breathwork, meditation, nutrition, and applied philosophy, Purna Yoga seeks to create greater health and ease not only in the body, but in one's attitude and general approach to life.

Purna Yoga classes start and finish with a short meditation to connect with the heart center. Following meditation, classes shift toward the practice of lyengar-style yoga postures, with careful emphasis on proper alignment. Instructors will share ancient wisdom from yogic philosophy.
Purna Yoga begins and ends sessions with a short meditation to connect with the heart center, then classes focus on Asana, pranayama, meditation, and nutrition.

item.title: Restorative Yoga
item.content:encoded: Restorative Yoga is designed to promote deep relaxation of the body in order to induce both physical and emotional rehabilitation. Classes utilize props so that practitioners can comfortably hold poses for long periods of time. Long holds allow the nervous system to relax, the musculoskeletal system to reorganize, and the body to heal. The benefits of Restorative Yoga include the healing of injuries and the release of trauma.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Restorative Yoga classes use props such as blocks, blankets, and straps to enable students to fully relax into each pose. Poses are held for long periods of time to encourage a deeply restful, meditative state in both body and mind. Restorative Yoga is frequently practiced before bedtime to promote optimal sleep.
Innovative yoga teacher and writer Judith Hanson Lasater helped to popularize Restorative Yoga, drawing on her studies under yoga master BKS Iyengar.

Restorative Yoga consists of restful poses that promote deep relaxation of the body for the purpose of physical and emotional healing. With the use of props, students hold poses for long periods of time, allowing the nervous system to relax and the musculoskeletal system to reorganize. Numerous studies have shown the healing benefits of Restorative Yoga, and it is often used for rehabilitation after injury or trauma.
Restorative Yoga is made up of relaxing and restful poses that rejuvenate and re-energize the body.
Discover the benefits of Restorative Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Rhythmic Flow Yoga
item.content:encoded: Rhythmic Flow Yoga is a style that combines flowing, Vinyasa-based movement sequences with the rhythm of Kunga drums. The drummer guides and inspires the class by creating a dynamic, creative, playful and energizing rhythm. The benefits of Rhythmic Flow Yoga include increased balance, flexibility, joy, energy, rejuvenation and weight loss.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Rhythmic Flow Yoga was developed by Kristin Cooper Gulak who aimed to create a style that would fuse together the rhythms of Kunga Drums with the flow of Yoga.

Rhythmic Flow Yoga combines a flowing Vinyasa Yoga practice with the rhythm of Kunga drums. The drummer guides and inspires the class by creating a playful, creative, and energizing rhythm. Live music may also be incorporated into the class. Rhythmic Flow Yoga offers a new, celebratory and community-oriented style of yoga practice.
Rhythmic Flow classes incorporate drums, music, and yoga to offer a unique, communal experience.
Rhythmic Flow Yoga is a variant of Vinyasa focusing especially on the rhythms of drums and other music to create a fun and fulfilling style of Yoga.

item.title: Sadhana Yoga Chi
item.content:encoded: Sadhana Yoga Chi aims to obtain balance by combining many yoga styles including Power Yoga, Restorative Yoga, and Vinyasa. Classes can be tailored for any level practitioner, and challenges students regardless of their levels of strength, flexibility, coordination, and balance. The benefits of Sadhana Yoga Chi include improved strength, flexibility, energy, focus and weight loss.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sadhana Yoga Chi draws from a variety of yoga styles, including Power Yoga, Restorative Yoga, Vinyasa, Ashtanga, and Yin Yoga, striving to weave them into a cohesive, balanced practice. Balance is central to Sadhana Yoga Chi: balance between teaching and learning, softness and power, fitness and intellect. The movements of Sadhana Yoga Chi are safe and applicable to all fitness and skill levels.

Sadhana Yoga Chi was developed by Doug Swenson to incorporate influences from a variety of different yoga systems into one practice. He began studying yoga in 1969, and has studied with several world-renowned yoga teachers.

A Sadhana Yoga Chi class will allow you to experience many styles of movement, alternating smooth, graceful, circular motions with powerful, strength-building poses, and flowing and poetic sequences with longer-held, individual yoga postures.

Sadhana Yoga Chi was developed by Doug Swenson to incorporate influences from a variety of different Yoga systems as well as the environment and nutrition. He began studying Yoga in 1969 and has studied with several world-renowned Yoga teachers.

item.title: Sanga Yoga
item.content:encoded: Sanga Yoga is a community-driven style of yoga that encourages individuals to find acceptance in one another. This unique practice relies on practitioners and teachers alike to share and experience the holistic and spiritual aspects of yoga together. The benefits of Sanga Yoga include improved energy, focus, balance, conscious awareness, and experience of divine wisdom.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sanga Yoga classes are ideal for all levels, and focus on providing an accessible, non-judgmental practice. Because the practice is community-oriented, students can expect to be encouraged to shift their focus from themselves to others, both literally and metaphorically.
Eric Paskel developed Sanga Yoga with the intention of providing a practice that is accessible to a wide audience and fosters social bonding and support.

Sanga Yoga is a community-driven style of yoga practice in which a group of individuals utilize yoga as a means for encouraging growth and acceptance in one another. Students are invited to find renewal by quieting the mind, animating the body, and enjoying the mutual benefits of a supportive, compassionate community.
Eric Paskel developed Sanga Yoga with the intention of providing a practice that is accessible to more individuals.

item.title: Satyananda Yoga
item.content:encoded: Satyananda Yoga incorporates all of the traditional branches of yogic philosophy. It was developed as a means of combining ancient texts with contemporary understandings, to create a synergistic effect for modern-day practitioners. The style is known as "integral" yoga because the objective is to harmonize all aspects of one’s being. The benefits of Satyananda Yoga include improved balance, flexibility, positivity, focus, confidence, inner peace, and the experience of higher consciousness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Satyananda Yoga is an integrative system of yoga that aims to present the ancient, classical yogic teachings in a way that is accessible to the modern day practitioner. Satyananda Yoga incorporates all of the traditional branches of yogic philosophy, offering a complete system for achieving well-being and harmony of the body, mind spirit and emotions.

A Satyananda Yoga class draws on ancient yogic philosophies but presents them through a contemporary lens. Physical postures are taught in a way that is designed to accommodate the needs of different individuals.
Swami Satyananda Saraswati developed Satyananda Yoga as a way to find peace in the modern world, offering ancient tools to help calm the mind and steady the emotions.
Satyananda Yoga provides an understandable approach to life without promoting political or religious beliefs; it offers the tools to achieve peace of mind, health and an inspired view of life.

item.title: Scaravelli Method
item.content:encoded: Scaravelli Yoga combines breathwork and gravity to help lengthen the spine. This style is specifically tailored for older individuals who may be new to yoga. The goal of this method is to release tension that surrounds the spine and allow freedom of movement to return. The benefits of the Scaravelli method are improved posture and balance, and healing from injury.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: During a Scarvelli class, students learn to yield to gravity with sharp exhales at the beginning of each movement.

Vanda Scaravelli developed the method in the years after World War II. She became passionate about yoga following the death of her husband, after which she began studying under the philosopher J. Krishnamurti and yogi B.K.S. Iyengar.

The Scarvelli method of yoga was specifically developed for older individuals who may be new to yoga. The practice is intended to release tension that surrounds the spine, allowing freedom of movement to return. Unlike other yoga styles which  depend on muscle strength to lengthen the spine, the Scarvelli method utilizes a combination of breath-work and gravity. The Scarvelli method has roots in Iyengar's principles of alignment, as well as Deskikachar's focus on breath.
Vanda Scaravelli Yoga with Sophie Whiting
Scaravelli Yoga encourages the lengthening of the spine through breathwork and yielding to gravity.
Discover the benefits of Scaravelli Method and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Shadow Yoga
item.content:encoded: Shadow Yoga is derived from Hatha Yoga texts, and keeps true to its ancient principles. This style of yoga consists of 12 postures and movements that were inspired by martial arts and dance. The benefits of Shadow Yoga include improved balance, flexibility, muscle tone, energy, and the experience of higher consciousness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Shadow Yoga was developed by Shandor Remete. The title comes from the 6th chapter on the Tantika Treatise, Yoga of the Shadow Man, and from the Ashtanga Hrdaya of Vagbhata, an Ayurvedic text in which the human body is described as frozen layers of shadows. The practice is intended to liberate one from these "shadows" or physical/mental/spiritual obstructions.

In a Shadow Yoga class, students engage in standing postures, flowing vinyasa sequences, and rhythmic breathing. Students begin with basic level classes and progress on to more advanced physical and philosophical teachings.

Shadow Yoga philosophy is based on ancient Hatha Yoga and Ayurvedic texts which use shadows as a metaphor for physical, mental and spiritual blocks. The practice of Shadow Yoga consists of a series of movements inspired by yoga, martial arts and dance. This free-flowing, rhythmic practice is designed to release tensions and energetic or emotional obstructions.
Shadow Yoga is a form of Hatha Yoga focused on removing shadows from the body by releasing tensions while developing mindfulness and strength.

item.title: Shambhava™ Yoga
item.content:encoded: Shambhava Yoga incorporates meditation, asana practice (postures) and selfless service. This style aims to bring wholeness to the physical bodt via a yoga form that ensures the natural curvature of the spine is aligned and emphasized. The benefits of Shambhava Yoga include improved posture, balance, flexibility, focus, clarity, conscious awareness, and access to inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sri Shambhavananda created Shambhava Yoga in 1975 with the goal of promoting timeless yoga teachings in a modern setting. There are multiple Shambhava Yoga affiliate centers and ashrams, all of which strive to guide visitors in using yoga to grow and improve their lives.

The physical practice of Shambhava Yoga involves exercises for maintaining the natural, aligned curvature of the spine. Classes typically start with a warmup, followed by asanas (physical postures), breathing exercises, and a brief meditation.

Shambhava Yoga presents the timeless teachings of yoga through a present-day practice that incorporates meditation, asana (postures), and selfless service. Students are encouraged to "combine heart-work and hard work," balancing spiritual development with activity in the world while using the practice of meditation to grow and rise above the challenges of everyday life.

item.title: Siddha Yoga
item.content:encoded: Siddha Yoga is a spiritually-oriented practice that seeks an inner mystical experience of oneness with God. Practitioners perform chanting and meditation in order to discover the divinity that rests within all of us. The benefits of Siddha Yoga include improved focus, clarity, connection to higher consciousness, wisdom, and the feeling of inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sri Kagapujandar built upon ancient yogic and spiritual practices to develop Siddha Yoga.

Siddha Yoga practices involve a range of techniques for experiencing one's spiritual nature, from meditation to hatha yoga postures to chanting to acts of selfless service. Community is an important aspect of Siddha Yoga, and students regularly engage in retreats to study and practice together.

Siddha Yoga is a spiritually-oriented practice that seeks an inner mystical experience of oneness with God. Through chanting, meditation, service, spiritual contemplation, and hatha yoga postures, Siddha Yoga practitioners seek to heighten awareness of the divine and to develop virtues such as love, detachment, and generosity. Practicing within a community of spiritual seekers is considered to enhance the effect of the practices.
Siddha Yoga emphasizes chanting, service, meditation techniques, and the importance of retreats.

item.title: Sivananda Yoga
item.content:encoded: Sivananda Yoga is an integrative yoga practice designed was created to elevate and transform the human consciousness. This style of yoga focuses on breathing, exercise, diet, relaxation, and meditation. Classes typically begin with meditative relaxation and finish with 12 basic asanas, or poses. The benefits of Sivananda Yoga include improved inner peace, focus, joy, conscious awareness, discipline, and a sense of empowerment.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Swami Vishnu-Devananda, the primary student of Swami Sivananda and a dedicated follower of his teachings, founded Sivananda Yoga in 1957.
Sivananda classes are typically 90 minutes long. A class includes Sanskrit chanting, the 12 core poses, meditation, pranayama practice (breathwork), and relaxation.

Sivananda Yoga is an integrative yoga practice designed was created to elevate and transform the human consciousness. It focuses on 5 major tenets of yoga: breathing, exercise, diet, relaxation, and meditation. These practices serve as the centerpiece through which spiritual teachings and verses are woven.
Sivananda Yoga classes are 90 minutes of spiritual exercises, which emphasize Sanskrit chanting, meditation, pranayama, and the 12 core poses.

item.title: Smart­FLOW®
item.content:encoded: SmartFLOW Yoga is an intelligent and organic system of yoga that focuses on alignment, strength, and breathing. Classes utilize traditional yoga poses with the addition of fluid movements and centered balances. The combination of traditional and modern techniques makes this style of yoga a unique fit for contemporary values. The benefits of SmartFlow Yoga include improved posture, strength, and mental clarity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: SmartFLOW Yoga uses mindful movement sequences and controlled breathing to build strength, improve alignment, and deepen concentration. The practice requires discipline and focus, and sharpens these abilities over time.

Annie Carpenter developed SmartFLOW Yoga after years of practicing yoga, leading retreats, and teaching workshops. SmartFLOW Yoga is a manifestation of her unique teaching style, emphasizing safe alignment and intelligent sequencing.

SmartFLOW Yoga is an intelligent and organic system of yoga that places emphasis on safe alignment, drawing upon aspects of developmental movement, biomechanics, kinesiology, and body structure. The practice combines traditional yoga poses with fluid movements and centered balances, placing attention on focused breathing.
SmartFLOW Yoga combines discipline with rigorous movement in an intelligent and organic system drawing on developmental movement and kinesiology.

item.title: Sri Sri Yoga
item.content:encoded: Sri Sri Yoga is a gentle style of yoga based mainly in Hatha traditions. Classes provide a well-rounded yoga experience by incorporating yoga postures, breathing, and meditation. Practitioners aim to experience the more subtle levels of being and consciousness through Sri Sri Yoga methods. The benefits of Sri Sri Yoga include improved energy, posture, balance and flexibility.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A basic Sri Sri Yoga class offers a well-rounded practice that combines Hatha Yoga postures with breathing techniques, meditation, and simple tools for relaxation. Level 2 classes offer insight into yoga scriptures and instruction in more advanced exercises.
Sri Sri Ravi Shankar developed the Sri Sri Yoga method to offer an integrative and accessible style of yoga that incorporates elements from various yoga traditions.

Sri Sri Yoga is an integrative yoga system that draws on various branches of yogic wisdom to guide students gently toward the blossoming of their full potential. Sri Sri Yoga practice includes Hatha yoga postures, breathing techniques, guided meditations and knowledge of Ayurveda, an ancient dietary and natural medicine system. Sri Sri Yoga is accessible to all experience levels.
Sri Sri Yoga combines Hatha Yoga with Asanas, breathing techniques, and meditations to discover the wisdom of Yoga, paving the way to full human potential.

item.title: Strala
item.content:encoded: Strala Yoga is an approach that is purely physical in application, and eschews philosophical or spiritual dogma. The studio's atmosphere and teachers strive to create a welcoming environment by remaining laid-back and unpretentious. The benefits of Strala Yoga include improved strength, balance, flexibility, energy, focus, mental clarity, and weight loss.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Strala Yoga is an energetic, dynamic, flowing style of yoga that keeps students actively engaged in fluid motion throughout the class.
Tara Stiles founded Strala Yoga with the intention of helping students clear the mind and body to connect with spirituality and intuition.

Strala Yoga is a physically-oriented approach to yoga that prides itself on being accessible, down to earth, and unpretentious. It is the perfect style for one hoping to glean the physical benefits of yoga without being immersed in the spiritual and mystical aspects common to most practices.
Strala Yoga focuses on moving with the breath, building strength, and realizing spirituality and personal intuition; it is suitable and helpful for all levels.

item.title: Svaroopa® Yoga
item.content:encoded: Svaroopa Yoga is a heavily guided and gentle form of yoga. The style focuses on releasing tension in the muscles that surround the spine. Classes make use of props to ease the practitioner into the various positions, which are specifically designed to restore proper alignment. The benefits of Svaroopa Yoga include improved posture, balance, flexibility, and revitalization.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Swami Nirmalananda Saraswati created Svaroopa Yoga as a method for "practicing Hatha yoga from the inside out." The word "Svaroopa" comes from the Yoga Sutra by Patanjali and refers to a transcendent inner experience, which is said to be the ultimate purpose of physical yoga practice.

Svaroopa Yoga practice works at opening up the spine by starting at the tailbone and moving through each spinal area in succession. Each pose is gently guided by the instructor, and props are often used to help the student achieve the proper position. The practice is accessible to students of all ages and abilities.

Svaroopa Yoga is a gentle, guided form of yoga that focuses on releasing tension in the muscles that surround the spine. This practice is intended to create healing and transformation not only on the physical level, but on the inner level as well. According to ancient yogic wisdom, the release of energy around the spine facilitates the experience of expanded states of consciousness.
Svaroopa Yoga opens up the spine from the tailbone up, working on each spinal section at a time by utilizing different methods of practicing common poses.
Discover the benefits of Svaroopa® Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Synergy Yoga
item.content:encoded: Synergy Yoga is an adaptive, modern form of yoga that can be made suitable for beginners and advanced practitioners alike. Classes take students progressively through 5 sequences, or elements, that comprise the style. These elements are often taught during corresponding seasons. The benefits of Synergy Yoga include improved balance, flexibility, strength, posture, and weight loss.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Synergy Yoga classes are typically organized around the seasons in order to activate the elemental qualities that are most needed at a particular time of year. So, for instance, movement sequences corresponding with the fire element are practiced during the winter in order to boost immunity and stamina during the colder months. The practice of Synergy Yoga is very harmonious with nature and with the Ayurvedic system of health.
Synergy Yoga was founded by Peri Ness DeFay, who began practicing yoga at a young age. DeFay created Synergy Yoga based on her experiences teaching, studying, and practicing Hatha Yoga.

Synergy Yoga is a flowing style of Hatha Yoga which is organized around the 5 basic elements of creation according to Ayurveda: Earth, Water, Fire, Air, and Ether. Each element has its own movement sequence which embodies the qualities of that element; the Earth sequence, for example, is grounding and cooling, while the Fire sequence is energizing and purifying. These elemental sequences are practiced at particular times of year to maintain a balance of elemental energies throughout the changing seasons.
Synergy Yoga is a flow based in the Hatha Yoga tradition, which is designed as a holistic system based on medical and scientific research to facilitate mental and physical healing.

item.title: Tantra
item.content:encoded: Tantra Yoga's main directive is to expand the consciousness and open one’s being to all layers of existence. The Tantra style of yoga uses breathing, meditation, visualization, and mantra to help practitioners reach their goal of experiencing the macrocosm. The benefits of Tantra Yoga include improved inner peace, focus, clarity, wisdom, positivity, and connection of higher consciousness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Tantra Yoga is an ancient practice rooted in spiritual tradition. In mainstream American culture, Tantra has become largely identified with a branch of practice that involves sexual contact between partners. Margot Anand's 1989 book The Art of Sexual Ecstasy and Charles Muir's Sacred Sexuality workshops have helped to popularize this modern style of Tantra.

In the West, the term "Tantra" is used for a wide variety of practices, some more classically rooted and some that have been blended with modern schools of thought. Some Tantric practices are internal only, involving meditations and exercises that work with the energy of the chakras. Other Tantric practices involve sexual contact and energy exchange between male and female partners. These partner exercises may have a spiritual goal or may be more oriented toward increasing intimacy between partners, incorporating elements of Western sexology and psychotherapy. It is best to research Tantra teachers individually to find out their approach.
Tantra Yoga teaches a spiritual approach to sex and consciousness, incorporating new age techniques, psychotherapy, and Eastern Spiritual and sexual methods.
Discover the benefits of Tantra and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Transformational Yoga
item.content:encoded: Transformational Yoga is an adaptive style of yoga that has integrated 6 traditional yoga methods. Class structure remains flexible so that each individual has the opportunity to make positive changes to their mind, body, and soul. The benefits of Transformational Yoga include improved balance, flexibility, strength, positivity, confidence, and the sense of inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: During a Transformational Yoga class, students will encounter traditional Hatha Yoga postures as well as aspects of mantra, pranayama, and meditation. Class structure remains flexible and adaptive so that each individual has the opportunity to make positive changes to their mind, body, and soul.
Transformational Hatha Yoga was developed by the Yoga Alliance International founder, Swami Vidyanand, in order to create an integral yogic system.

Transformational Yoga is an integral yoga system consisting of asana (postures), mantra, meditative techniques, and pranayama (breathwork) to purify the body on four major levels: emotional, spiritual, mental, and physical. Developed by master yogi Swami Vidyanand, Transformational Yoga draws on a variety of ancient yogic traditions to form an innovative approach to dealing with the stresses of modern life, leading practitioners on a journey of integrating the mind, spirit, and body.
Transformational Yoga combines Asanas, Hatha Yoga, Mantra, and meditative techniques to purify the body on emotional, spiritual, mental, and physical levels.

item.title: TriYoga®
item.content:encoded: TriYoga is a style of yoga that places an emphasis on posture, breath, and focus. All movements associated with this style of yoga revolve around wave-like motions of the spine. Classes target each vertebra separately, moving up the spinal ladder one at a time. The benefits of TriYoga include improved posture, flexibility, balance, and healing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Triyoga is a creative, relaxing practice, often practiced to music. The practice can be gentle or challenging, depending on the level. Triyoga classes are organized into seven levels of instruction, although it is not uncommon for students at varying levels to practice all together. Students focus on moving with precise alignment and minimal effort, building strength, flexibility, balance, and breath control.
Kali Ray (Kaliji) developed the Triyoga method in 1980, while she was leading group meditation. She established the TriYoga Center in Santa Cruz, California in 1986 .

TriYoga is an innovative yoga style that combines asana (poses), pranayama (rhythmic breathing), and mudra (symbolic hand gestures) in a series of flowing, dance-like movements. The movements are meditative and deliberate, with focus on alignment, economy of motion, and relaxation in action. The transition from one posture to the next results in a wave-like motion of the spine, stimulating the kundalini energy.
TriYoga uses dance-like movements in a flowing series to create a slow, rejuvenating practice focused on breath and alignment.

item.title: Hatha Yoga / Mixed Styles
item.content:encoded: "Various Styles" refers to a conglomerate of yoga traditions that draws from different practices. Various Styles offers a diverse, custom-tailored approach to students, allowing them an opportunity to better experience the multifaceted and adaptable nature of yoga.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Hatha Yoga was developed in 15th century India by Yogi Swatmarama, who was a compiler of Hatha Yoga Pradipika. Modern Hatha was developed from the school of Sri Tirumalai Krishnamacharya, whose students include the Ashtanga Vinyasa founder, Sri K. Pattabhi Jois. The original teachings of Hatha Yoga have since branched out into the variety of yoga styles that exist today.

Hatha Yoga classes make a great introduction to traditional yoga. The practice generally involves slower-paced stretches and balancing poses in conjunction with breathing exercises. The combination of mindful movement and focused breathing helps to relax and tone the body, improve circulation and oxygenation, and relieve stress. Because Hatha is considered a generic of yoga style, classes may vary greatly from teacher to teacher, drawing on different yoga traditions and emphasizing different aspects of the practice.

Many workshops, retreats, and even teacher trainings have incorporated into their schedules and curricula several approaches to practicing Yoga; this variety in style gives attendees a chance to better experience the multifaceted and personally adaptable nature of Yoga.

item.title: Vijñâna Yoga
item.content:encoded: Vijñâna Yoga is derived from the yogic tradition of Northern India, and focuses on acting from within. The programs for this yoga style are crafted from the 7 Vital Principles, and focus heavily on obtaining true alignment. The benefits of Vijñâna Yoga include improved mental clarity, focus, balance, posture, energy, and inner peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Orit Sen-Gupta created Vijñâna Yoga as a culmination of her experience and study of classical yogic practices and yogis texts. The word "Vijñâna" refers to a deep knowing that is revealed through personal experience.
During a Vijñâna Yoga class, students can expect to practice extensive breathing exercises, alignment-based poses, and meditation, as well as engage in the study of sacred yoga texts.

Vijñâna Yoga is derived from the yogic tradition of northern India, which inspired the teachings of renowned yogis Pattabhi Jois, B.K.S. Iyengar and T.K.V. Desikachar. The practice of Vijñâna Yoga consists of four parts: alignment-based poses, pranayama (breathwork), meditation, and study of classical yogic texts. By practicing all four of these together, the student reaches an integrated, embodied understanding of the deep wisdom of yoga.
Teresa Caldas: What is Vijñāna Yoga?
Vijñâna uses extensive breathing exercises, alignment poses, and meditation to deepen intuition and form a more easily accessible pathway for life.

item.title: Viniyoga
item.content:encoded: Viniyoga is an approach that incorporates participation in order to cater to each individual's unique conditions, expectations, and needs. Correct positioning during poses is not guided with strictness, and the student's comfort is valued over aesthetic perfection. The benefits of Viniyoga include improved posture, flexibility, balance, energy, and recovery from injury.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Gary Kraftsow developed Viniyoga from the teachings of T. Krishnamacharya and T.K.V. Desikachar, with the aim of creating an adaptive approach to yoga that fits the needs of each individual.

Viniyoga is typically taught through individualized sessions, so that the teacher can adapt the practice to suit the particular needs of the student. The student will engage in traditional yogic poses, but the emphasis is on function rather than form. Poses may be held longer, repeated several times, or sequenced in a unique way for the student.

Viniyoga is a uniquely individualized approach to yoga. While authentically based on classical yogic teachings, Viniyoga adapts the methods of practice to accommodate each student's unique conditions, interests, and needs. The practice of Viniyoga draws on all the traditional aspects of yoga, including physical poses, breathwork, meditation, chanting, and scriptural study.
ViniYoga encompasses a wide range of Yoga teachings and practices, adapting them to meet the unique needs and conditions of each individual.

item.title: Vinyasa Flow Yoga
item.content:encoded: Vinyasa or Vinyasa Flow Yoga is the backbone for many yoga styles. It is one of the most popular styles of yoga in the Western world, serving as the cornerstone for a significant proportion of classes. The essence of this style is marked by a synchrony between each movement and each breath. Vinyasa classes differ greatly among one another, because there is no universal standard for application. Practitioners from all levels tend to enjoy this physically-oriented style. The benefits of Vinyasa Yoga include improved confidence, positivity, balance, and flexibility.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Krishnamacharya, a world-famous Yoga teacher born in 1888 in India, developed Vinyasa Yoga to integrate the benefits of yoga asana (movement) with the benefits of controlled breathing.

Vinyasa is a faster-paced yoga style that will keep you moving throughout the class. The synchrony between each movement and breath requires focus, makes this practice a workout for both the body and the mind.

Vinyasa or Vinyasa Flow Yoga is a highly popular form of yoga which serves as the backbone of many modern yoga styles. The practice of Vinyasa consists of a series of poses that flow from one to the next, with mindful attention placed on the synchrony between movement and breath. The continuous movement makes this style of yoga a particularly well-rounded physical exercise, with aerobic benefits as well as those of increased strength and flexibility. In addition, the practice of mindful intention and harnessing the calming power of breath teaches students to manage stress better in their daily lives.
Vinyasa Yoga uses rhythms, sequences, Asanas, and breath to provide a balance in students’ lives both on and off the mat.

item.title: White Lotus Yoga
item.content:encoded: White Lotus Yoga can be gentle or challenging, depending on a student's skill and comfort levels. Classes for this style perform poses while using breathing techniques and meditation exercises. Synchronizing breath with alignment is also a distinguishing foundation of this style. The benefits of White Lotus Yoga include improved balance, flexibility, strength, confidence, and positivity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: During a White Lotus Yoga class, students engage in a flowing, Vinyasa-style practice with an emphasis on coordination between breath and movement. The class is taught with a flexible, open-minded approach that strives to make practice enjoyable and adaptable to many different skill levels. Classes may also include meditation exercises and theoretical knowledge of yoga.

White Lotus Yoga was developed by Ganga White and Tracey Rich, a husband and wife team with assorted backgrounds in various yogic traditions. White Lotus Yoga was created to offer a flexible teaching approach and promote a deeper understanding of the mind-body connection.

White Lotus Yoga in a non-dogmatic style of yoga that draws on a variety of traditional yoga styles, blending and adapting them into a personalized practice for each student. White Lotus Yoga can be either gentle or challenging, depending upon the student's skill and comfort levels. The practice involves flowing sequences of poses with synchronized breathing, similar to Ashtanga and Vinyasa styles.
White Lotus approaches Yoga in a flexible and enjoyable manner that can be adapted by different skill levels to be gentle or challenging.

item.title: Yantra Yoga
item.content:encoded: Yantra Yoga refers simply to the yoga of movement. It is one of the oldest forms of yoga that exists. Practitioners focus on geometric shapes and patterns during meditation in order to observe the way energy manifests in the physical world. The benefits of Yantra Yoga include improved focus, clarity, peacefulness, and connection to higher consciousness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: During a Yantra Yoga class, students practice a unique series of movements that are linked with specific breathing techniques. Students may also engage in meditative visualization of abstract geometric shapes and patterns, which are understood to illustrate the way energy manifests in the physical world.
Yantra Yoga, which originated in Tibet, is one of the oldest documented systems of yoga. It displays numerous similarities to another ancient system of yoga, Hatha Yoga.

Yantra Yoga is an ancient yoga system from Tibet. The practice involves a series of postures similar to those of Hatha Yoga, but the postures are assumed and applied in a unique way, with an emphasis on the entire movement, not just the final pose. Yantra Yoga highlights seven sequential phases of movement that are connected with seven phases of breathing. This conscious coordination of breath and movement, along with mental visualization, is used to harmonize the body's vital energy and relax the mind.
Yantra Yoga features unique series of movements and positions to harmonize personal energy and relax the mind, aiding in the discovering of the student’s authentic base.
Discover the benefits of Yantra Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Yâpana Yoga
item.content:encoded: Yâpana Yoga is a unique, creative blend of Vinyasa Flow Yoga and Restorative Yoga. that makes use of props in order to activate therapeutic healing within the body. Achieving proper alignment, elongating the spine, and engaging in deep, long holds are central to this style. Classes are easily adaptable for each practitioner's needs. The benefits of Yapana Yoga include improved energy, strength, posture, and healing capacity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: With over 25 years of yoga experience, Leeann Carey developed Yâpana Yoga with the goal of creating a practice that can be modified to meet the needs of each unique individual.

During a Yâpana Yoga class, students begin with basic warm-up poses, progress to a more dynamic, flowing series of postures, and conclude with longer, relaxed holds, often involving the use of props. Classes are easily adaptable to the needs of each student.

Yâpana Yoga is a unique, creative blend of Vinyasa Flow Yoga and Restorative Yoga. The dynamic, flowing Vinyasa poses serve to warm up the body and prepare it for the longer, deeper holds characteristic of Restorative Yoga. Props are used to help achieve the longer poses, allowing the body to relax deeply into each posture for maximum therapeutic benefit.
Yâpana Yoga students use props for therapeutic support, blending a variety of different Yoga styles, including Vinyasa Flow.
Discover the benefits of Yâpana Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Yin Yoga
item.content:encoded: Yin Yoga was created to focus on relieving tension and healing injury within the ligaments and tendons of the joints and spine. Classes are gentle, and poses may be held for minutes at a time. The goal of Yin Yoga is to ultimately return elasticity to connective tissue, unwind deep muscular tensions, and ultimately give the body space to heal. The benefits of Yin Yoga include improved flexibility and unlocking the body's innate potential for healing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Yin Yoga is derived from the Chinese philosophy of Taoism. The practice of Yin Yoga consists of slower, more passive poses to balance the more active, "yang" energy of other yoga styles. Yin Yoga poses are held for longer periods, releasing tension in the connective tissues and stimulating circulation in the joints. The practice of Yin Yoga is said to improve the flow of chi or subtle energy in the body, which supports immunity and emotional well-being.

In a Yin Yoga class, students engage in deep, sustained holds, surrendering effort and maintaining patient, mindful awareness. The atmosphere of a Yin Yoga class supports ease of mind and non-judgment of self.

Taoist yoga teacher Paulie Zink developed Yin Yoga after practicing martial arts with the master Cho Chat Ling. Zink developed Yin Yoga to help practitioners discover techniques to ease their bodies into unwinding from the physical demands of daily life, while also cultivating the mind.
Yin Yoga, derived from Taoism, helps students to improve health and balance their emotions through multiple variations, perceptions and postures.
Discover the benefits of Yin Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Yoga for Children
item.content:encoded: Yoga for Children is a general term used to describe yoga classes geared toward younger practitioners. Yoga for Children can be adapted from any yoga style. Yoga can serve as a powerful tool for young bodies and minds, aiding them with many of the developmental stages that can often be difficult. Classes generally add a playful element to keep young practitioners engaged. The benefits of Yoga for Children include building confidence and positivity, and strengthening the body and relationship to oneself.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Yoga for Children offers kids a fresh and playful introduction to the benefits of yoga. Engaging children with movement, music, and role-playing, Yoga for Children classes help kids build strength and coordination while learning about the mind-body connection. Children may also be taught helpful techniques for relaxation and centering.

Yoga for Children classes are designed to be fun and playful, often incorporating music and rhythm to keep kids engaged. Traditional yoga postures are adapted so that they can be safely practiced by children of all ages.

With the increasing popularization of yoga in the West over the last half century, yoga teachers inevitably began teaching yoga to their own children. Some teachers led school children in yoga exercises as a way to help kids calm down and focus. Today, many yoga centers offers classes uniquely for children.
Yoga for Children provides a safe and entertaining atmosphere for children to improve strength, coordination, and relaxation.
Discover the benefits of Yoga for Kids and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Yoga Philosophy
item.content:encoded: Yoga Philosophy focuses on understanding the extremes of life, nature, and existence. Indian Sanskrit literature refers to yoga as, "the process of uniting the self with the Divine." Yoga Philosophy emphasizes the study of yoga as more than just a form of physical exercise, but rather as a means to become closer to God.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Yoga Philosophy is derived from ancient Indian Sanskrit texts and interpreted by a long lineage of practicing yogis and yoginis.

Yoga Philosophy offers ancient wisdom for living a more fulfilled, healthy, and peaceful life in harmony with nature and divine law. The elements of yoga philosophy range from practical knowledge about wellness and stress resistance to ethics and techniques for experiencing higher states of consciousness.

Yoga is an ancient practice that is based in an even more ancient philosophy. Literally "union" in Sanskrit, yoga is described in the ancient Indian literature as "the process of uniting the self with the Divine." Yoga Philosophy articulates the relationship between physical and spiritual reality and outlines techniques for realizing one's full human potential.
Yoga Philosophy seeks to unite the Self with the Divine, regarding Yoga as more than simply physical exercise, but a path to become closer to God.
Discover the benefits of Yoga Philosophy and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Yoga Therapy
item.content:encoded: Yoga Therapy is a system that combines modern medical practices with yoga. Recognizing its deeply therapeutic potential, various Health Care Providers have begun to integrate yoga into their wellness plans and prescriptions for healing. Classes are tailored to an individual’s specific injury or condition, and all activities are performed with the focus on healing. A major benefit of Yoga Therapy includes the promotion of a healing internal environment.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Yoga Therapy is generally practiced in individual or small group settings and guided by a specialist. The practice is tailored to the individual's needs and typically consists of physical movements, breathing exercises, and relaxation techniques.

Yoga Therapy combines modern medical and physical therapy practices with the ancient techniques of yoga to offer a well-rounded approach to healing and rehabilitation. Widely recognized for its therapeutic value, Yoga Therapy is often practiced in a clinical setting, offering relief to those struggling with injuries and chronic pain.

Yoga Therapy became popularized in the U.S. in the late 1980s, after Dr. Dean Ornish published a groundbreaking study showing how lifestyle changes, including diet, therapeutic yoga and meditation, could reverse heart disease. His program for reversal of heart disease became approved for health insurance coverage, making yoga therapy an accepted medical practice, and opening the way for many subsequent studies on the benefits of therapeutic yoga for other health conditions.
Yoga Therapy combines Yoga teaching and practice with applicable medical techniques to help treat common ailments and sufferings.
Discover the benefits of Yoga Therapy and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: Yoga Tune Up®
item.content:encoded: Yoga Tune Up is a full-body fitness system which combines calisthenics and yoga. The program aims to increase overall strength, introduce healing to the musculoskeletal system, and improve the immune system. Classes work the entire body, from muscle tissue to tendons, joints, and connective tissue. The benefits of Yoga Tune Up include improved strength, energy, endurance, and weight loss.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Jill Miller created Yoga Tune Up to provide a system of yoga that incorporates traditional aspects of yoga with a strong focus on conditioning and healing the body.

During a Yoga Tune Up class, students can expect a very physically-oriented practice that targets all aspects of the body, from muscles and tendons to joints and connective tissues. The class may also incorporate yoga philosophy.

Yoga Tune Up is a full-body fitness system that is centered around corrective exercise, calisthenics, and yoga. Specifically formulated to increase overall strength, Yoga Tune Up can serve as a powerful tool to bring about healing within the musculoskeletal system. Its restorative techniques serve to create flexibility and balance while relieving injuries, lowering stress, and improving coordination.
Yoga Tune Up uses corrective exercise and calisthenics to increase overall strength and improve immunity.
Discover the benefits of Yoga Tune Up® and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

item.title: YogaFit®
item.content:encoded: YogaFit was developed to be adapted to any level practitioner, but to also be challenging and grow dramatic changes. The program offers different variations of classical poses found in the Hatha traditions. The benefits of YogaFit include improved strength, balance, flexibility, posture, and muscle tone.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: YogaFit was developed to improve the performance, mental acuity, and health of athletes and active individuals. The practice consists of Hatha Yoga poses in a flowing format designed to improve strength, balance, power, and flexibility. YogaFit strives to make yoga accessible, user-friendly, and practical to modern-day practitioners at various fitness levels.

YogaFit classes incorporate aspects of traditional Hatha Yoga with contemporary fitness practices to create a modern, athlete-friendly practice. It has eliminated Sanskrit terminology and meditative aspects to encourage novices.
YogaFit was created by Beth Shaw in 1994 with the intention of using yoga as a medium to help athletes and individuals improve their levels of fitness, while also calming and clarifying the mind.
YogaFit blends strength, balance, power and flexibility to increase the level of fitness of the practitioner.
Discover the benefits of YogaFit® and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
YogaFit YogaFit instructor YogaFit classes benefits of YogaFit Balance and Flexibility Be Challenged Energize and Improve Strength Improve Posture Tone Muscles and Lose Weight Unlock Inner Power

item.title: Yogalosophy
item.content:encoded: Yogalosophy is a unique style of yoga, which was developed to unwind the mind while promoting the development of long, lean muscles. The program is easy to follow, but challenging in application. Yoga poses are partnered with toning exercises to deliver an accelerated approach to strengthening the body. The benefits of Yogalosophy include improved flexibility, strength, focus, and weight loss.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A Yogalosophy class incorporates traditional yoga postures with strengthening exercises, providing an invigorating workout geared toward improving overall fitness.
Yogalosophy was created by Mandy Ingber, who has helped numerous celebrities, including Jennifer Aniston, improve their fitness levels, lose weight, and calm their minds through yoga.

Yogalosophy is a unique style of yoga developed to unwind the mind while sculpting long, lean muscles. Yogalosophy tones both the internal and external body through an easy-to-follow, sweat-inducing routine.
Yogalosophy is a revolutionary style developed to relax and unwind the mind through traditional Yoga postures that also improve overall physical fitness and shape.
Discover the benefits of Yogalosophy and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

Yogalosophy Yogalosophy instructor Yogalosophy classes benefits of Yogalosophy Balance and Flexibility Be Challenged Energize and Improve Strength Improve Focus and Clarity Improve Posture Tone Muscles and Lose Weight

Bhakti Yoga is the path to spiritual enlightenment through devotion. According to ancient Hindu scripture, practicing an attitude of devotion to the Divine purifies the heart and mind and cultivates an awareness of the presence of the Divine in daily life. Bhakti Yoga uses practices such as chanting, ritual, meditation and prayer to keep one’s mind and heart fixed on god. The relationship between a disciple and a spiritual guru is also seen as a medium for developing a personal relationship with the Divine. Acts of service and love for the guru are offered as a way to demonstrate devotion and surrender to god.

The most popular form of Bhakti Yoga practice is kirtan, ecstatic singing or chanting of the names of god, usually in groups and with musical accompaniment. Other practices may include meditation on an image of the Divine, listening to scriptural stories, prayer, worship ceremonies, or acts of service.

The tradition of Bhakti Yoga is often linked to the Bhagavad Gita, an ancient Hindu scripture known as a “love song to God”, which expressed the idea that pure, heartfelt devotion to God is a path to spiritual realization. Bhakti Yoga practice is unique for being universally accessible, requiring no special study or physical accomplishment, and has welcomed practitioners of any social class or gender throughout its history.
Discover the benefits of Bhakti Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

Bhakti Yoga Bhakti Yoga instructor Bhakti Yoga classes benefits of Bhakti Yoga Sky Akasha Charu Rachlis Wade Imre Morissette Krishna Das Michael Johnson Alanna Kaivalya Saul David Raye Sharon Gannon David Life

Ayurveda is an ancient Indian natural wellness system that dates back several thousand years and is still practiced today. The Sanskrit word “Ayurveda” translates as “The Knowledge and Science of Life.” Ayurveda describes three primary life-forces or “doshas” that make up all of nature and are manifest in the human body: Vata, associated with the air element; Pitta, associated with the fire element; and Kapha, associated with the earth and water elements. According to Ayurveda, each individual’s unique physical/emotional/mental constitution is made up of a particular combination of these doshas, which must be kept in proper balance in order to maintain wellness. Ayurveda uses a combination of natural remedies and therapies, diet and lifestyle factors to adjust the doshas back into balance.

Ayurveda views each person’s constitution as unique, and therefore, each person’s path to wellness as unique. For this reason, Ayurvedic consultations are very personalized. The practitioner will observe the patient’s physical characteristics and speech patterns, feel the patient’s pulse, and ask questions about the patient’s lifestyle habits and general well-being. After establishing the patient’s constitution of doshas, the practitioner will prescribe treatments to balance the doshas, which may include nutrition, bodywork, herbal remedies, and recommendations for exercise, meditation, and daily routine.

Ayurveda originated as an oral tradition 5,000 years ago in India and was recorded in the Vedas, India’s sacred literature. It is said to have influenced the Chinese and Greek systems of natural medicine. Today, Ayurveda is still widely practiced in India, and has begun to gain popularity in the West, especially in the last decade.
Discover the benefits of Ayurveda and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

Hiking Yoga is just what it sounds like: a complementary blend of outdoor hiking and yoga. Groups are led on a medium-paced hike through local terrain, with regular stops to do yoga poses and breathing exercises. The hiking adds a fun cardio element to the yoga workout, while the yoga helps to stretch muscles and ligaments and rotate joints, keeping the body loose and injury-free during the hike. The fresh air proves especially cleansing for breathing exercises, and the sights, sounds and smells of nature help soothe the nervous system.

Hiking yoga is very accessible to those who are new to yoga or to hiking. The hikes are relatively easy, and the yoga poses are usually familiar to anyone who has taken an occasional class. Hiking yoga is also a uniquely social form of yoga. Groups are free to chat away as they explore their local environment. Instructors often engage participants in partner yoga poses to encourage the communal spirit.
Eric Kipp began leading yoga hikes in San Francisco in 2009. Since then, hiking yoga has become a national trend, popularized through social media.
Discover the benefits of Hiking Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Hiking Yoga Hiking Yoga instructor Hiking Yoga classes benefits of Hiking Yoga Laurie Sleep Eric Kipp

Slackline Yoga is the practice of yoga poses while balancing on a slackline, a 1” piece of webbing tensioned between two points. This challenging practice requires great focus, breath control, and core strength. Balancing on the slackline requires a smooth and steady flow between each pose, making Slackline Yoga a unique form of Vinyasa. The practice can be made more or less difficult depending upon how long the slackline is.

Before doing yoga on a slackline, you have to learn how to stand on it without falling off. Eventually, however, you can move into various yoga poses, including standing, sitting, and kneeling postures, and even arm balances and inversions. To get started, try a workshop or an instructional DVD that explains how to do this practice safely.

Slackline Yoga was created in 2005 by Sam Salwei and Jason Magness, two yoga and climbing enthusiasts who had begun to experiment with slacklining. They formed the company YogaSlackers, which has since trained many thousands of people in the art of Slackline Yoga.
Discover the benefits of Slackline Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

Yoga with Weights: Baptiste method is a unique exercise system that combines a mindful yoga practice with targeted bodybuilding for overall physical fitness. Breath-based hatha yoga postures are practiced with the addition of small ankle or hand-held weights. The practice alternately contracts and stretches the muscles for increased strength and toning, flexibility and coordination.

Yoga with Weights classes place emphasis on proper alignment and on the coordination of breath and movement, increasing mindful focus and safety during practice. The addition of small weights helps build strength and tone targeted areas of the body. The exercises can be modified to accommodate those who are pregnant or older.
Yoga with Weights: Baptiste method was developed by Sherri Baptiste, the daughter of power yoga pioneer Walt Baptiste and sister of well-known power yoga leader Baron Baptiste.
TimeToYoga : Yoga with Weights: Baptiste Method
Discover the benefits of Yoga with Weights: Baptiste Method and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.

Yoga for Seniors classes are designed for older practitioners and their unique physical challenges. Traditional yoga poses are modified to accommodate more limited movement and more delicate bones, and props may be used to help ease students into poses safely and gently. Classes focus on postures that increase flexibility, circulation and ease of movement, counteracting the spine- and joint-stiffening effects of age. The practice of yoga for seniors has been demonstrated to ease age-related health conditions such as arthritis, bone weakness, and high blood pressure, blood sugar and cholesterol levels. Other benefits include improved energy levels, reduced stress, more balanced hormones, and better mental and physical fitness.

Yoga for Seniors classes are gentle and non-competitive. A variety of poses are practiced to help develop flexibility, strength, and balance, but the poses are held for shorter periods and are modified with the use of props to avoid strain and risk of injury. Meditation and breathing exercises may also be incorporated into a class.

There have always been seniors who practice yoga, but never before have there been so many seniors learning yoga for the first time. The recent explosion of yoga’s popularity in the West and the accumulation of scientific studies on the health and therapeutic benefits of yoga has helped to spread yoga practice throughout all levels of society. As a result, more and more yoga teachers are designing classes specifically for older practitioners.
Discover the benefits of Yoga for Seniors and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Yoga for Seniors Yoga for Seniors instructor Yoga for Seniors classes benefits of Yoga for Seniors Denese Cavanaugh Desirée Rumbaugh

SHAKTI Vinyasa yoga is a moderately challenging form of vinyasa based on the idea of fluid, wave-like movements and flowing sequences that follow a circular form. SHAKTI Vinyasa is set to the pulse of music and regulated breathing, making each movement feel intentional and disciplined, yet expressive. Postures may include arm balancing, back bends, inversions, and hip openers.

SHAKTI Vinyasa is recommended for those who have at least six months of other vinyasa experience. The practice is powerful yet graceful, with flowing sequences of postures and synchronized breathing. The studio is heated, but only to about 90 degrees, helping to loosen the body. Classes may incorporate music and chanting, philosophy and moving meditation.

SHAKTI Vinyasa yoga was created in 2003 by Lisa Black, drawing on the postures and philosophies of power yoga pioneer Baron Baptiste, master vinyasa teacher Shiva Rea, and restorative yoga luminary Ana Forrest.
Discover the benefits of SHAKTI Vinyasa Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
SHAKTI Vinyasa Yoga SHAKTI Vinyasa Yoga instructor SHAKTI Vinyasa Yoga classes benefits of SHAKTI Vinyasa Yoga Lisa Black

Kripalu Yoga Dance is one of the most free-form of yoga styles. It is a combination of guided, flowing yoga postures and opportunities for individualized expression. The practice is based around the chakras, or seven energy centers of the body, and is designed to tap into each energy, from the earthy root chakra up through the heart chakra to the spiritual crown chakra. Through this practice, students are empowered to tap into their inner rhythm and innate joy.

Kripalu Yoga Dance can be practiced by any body and any experience level. It is a fun, flowing series of movements ranging from dynamic to graceful to meditative. Students are guided through some traditional yoga postures, but there is not a strict set of rules for how to move or any complicated choreography. The practice is set to an eclectic range of world music for a light-hearted, upbeat vibe, and the atmosphere is supportive and non-judgmental.

In 1980, the well-known Kripalu Yoga Center began a program fusing yoga and dance, called DansKinetics. Later, the practice was trademarked as Kripalu Yoga Dance. Today, there are several personalized variations of this practice taught by Kripalu Center alumni such as Megha-Nancy Buttenheim, Beth Rigby and David Leven.
Discover the benefits of Kripalu Yoga Dance and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Kripalu Yoga Dance Kripalu Yoga Dance instructor Kripalu Yoga Dance classes benefits of Kripalu Yoga Dance Jovinna Chan

Stand-Up Paddleboard Yoga or SUP Yoga combines two of today’s most popular fitness trends: yoga and stand-up paddleboard. In SUP Yoga, a paddleboard is used as a floating yoga mat. Students are challenged to remain balanced on the board while transitioning through a series of yoga postures. The practice helps to develop core strength and mental focus while adding a refreshing outdoor element to the yoga experience.

It is recommended that students have some experience with basic stand-up paddleboard before attempting SUP Yoga. In an SUP yoga class, students will typically warm up on land with a few basic yoga poses, then paddle out to a calm space of water and begin balancing on the board. Students may begin with kneeling or sitting postures, which keep the center of gravity low, and then progress to more challenging standing poses. Don’t be afraid to fall and get wet!

Stand-up paddleboard began in Hawaii in the 1960s, while yoga is thousands of years old, but both practices have exploded in popularity in the last few decades. It was perhaps inevitable that these two popular forms of exercise would be combined into a hot new fitness trend that has taken off all over the country.
Discover the benefits of Stand-Up Paddleboard Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Stand-Up Paddleboard Yoga Stand-Up Paddleboard Yoga instructor Stand-Up Paddleboard Yoga classes benefits of Stand-Up Paddleboard Yoga Sandra Tedeschi Danielle Gentilcore

The Kaivalya Yoga method is a holistic practice designed to engage all aspects of one’s being and to set students on a path to embodied self-knowledge and self-empowerment. Through the physical practice of yoga; the vibrational experience of music, breath, and mantra; and the understanding revealed through philosophical and mythological stories; students are provided with with tools to become tuned to their own inner knowing.

The practice of Kaivalya Yoga combines intelligent vinyasa sequences with rhythmic breath, music, and mantra to create a ritualistic experience that engages the whole body and psyche. Teachers provide hands-on assistance with poses and introduce concepts from mythology, philosophy and psychology to guide students toward a deeper understanding of self.

Alanna Kaivalya developed the Kaivalya Yoga method as a culmination of her decade-plus experience teaching yoga and studying mythology, depth-psychology and spiritual traditions. She has recently begun offering teacher training programs in her signature yoga style.
Discover the benefits of Kaivalya Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Kaivalya Yoga Kaivalya Yoga instructor Kaivalya Yoga classes benefits of Kaivalya Yoga Alanna Kaivalya

Zenyasa is a unique form of yoga that incorporates elements of Zen Buddhism and principles from exercise science. The practice includes “slow-flow” vinyasa yoga poses, meditation, breathing exercises, and strength training exercises, with an emphasis on mindfulness. Exercises are organized around the 5 elements of Chinese medicine--earth, metal, fire, water, and wood--which are each associated with different muscle groups and energy meridians in the body. Classes are themed around each element in turn, ensuring a balanced practice.

Zenyasa classes begin with a Buddhist meditation to still the mind. Classical formalities such as bowing to the mat, acknowledging the teacher and the class, and invoking a simple prayer of goodwill for all beings, pay respect to the lineage of the Eastern traditions. After a simple warm-up series to loosen the joints, the class will be devoted to exercises that are themed around one of the five elements, with an equal balance between strengthening and stretching exercises.

Zenyasa was created by Jason Ray Brown, a yoga teacher, massage therapist, and student of the Buddhist monk Thich Naht Hahn, who wanted to incorporate his Zen Buddhist studies as well as his studies in exercise science into his yoga practice.
Discover the benefits of Zenyasa and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Zenyasa Zenyasa instructor Zenyasa classes benefits of Zenyasa Chris Loebsack

Anjali Restorative Yoga is a deeply healing practice designed to relax and open the body, mind and heart. The practice combines gentle yoga postures that lengthen the spine with other therapeutic elements to soothe the senses, such as aromatherapy, music, and uplifting, poetic language. The atmosphere of softness and well-being encourages students to let go of the tension and stress of their busy modern lives.

Anjali Restorative Yoga classes strive to create a soothing, nourishing environment, with spa-like touches such as gentle music, aromatherapy and eye pillows. The restorative yoga postures are supported with bolsters and soft blankets and held for long periods of time, allowing the body and mind to deeply relax. Classes may incorporate guided meditations, massage, and inspirational literature.
Anjali Restorative Yoga was founded in 2004 by Shannon Page. It is highly regarded as a form of therapy that speaks to emotional as well as physical stress.
Discover the benefits of Anjali Restorative Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Anjali Restorative Yoga Anjali Restorative Yoga instructor Anjali Restorative Yoga classes benefits of Anjali Restorative Yoga Shannon Paige

Insight Yoga is a unique yoga style that weaves traditional yoga postures with insights from Buddhism, Taoism, and Transpersonal Psychology to create an integral practice for the body, mind, and heart. The physical practice of Insight Yoga balances gentle “Yin” style floor poses with a slow-flow “Yang” series of postures drawn from classical Ashtanga and Iyengar and influenced by Viniyoga and Qi Gong. Meditation and breathing exercises are also incorporated to encourage mindfulness and non-reactivity.

During an Insight Yoga class, students are guided through a combination of receptive “yin” poses and active “yang” poses, as well as Buddhist-style mindfulness meditation. Concepts from Buddhist philosophy, Chinese medicine, and transpersonal psychology are subtly woven into the instruction to give context to each practice.

Insight Yoga was created by Sarah Powers and draws on her 25 years of yoga teaching, educational background in Transpersonal Psychology, and in-depth training in the Vipassana, Tantric and Dzogchen practices of Buddhism.
Discover the benefits of Insight Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Insight Yoga Insight Yoga instructor Insight Yoga classes benefits of Insight Yoga Ty Powers Sarah Powers

Align Your Flow is a mindful form of vinyasa flow yoga that emphasizes carefully aligned postures and synchrony of breath and movement as a way to develop heightened body-mind awareness. The purpose of Align Your Flow practice is to learn to be more present in daily life and more conscious of one’s actions both on and off the yoga mat.

Align Your Flow combines a dynamic, flowing practice with careful attention on alignment and breath. The emphasis on alignment ensures a safe practice and a clear, focused mind, while the vinyasa provides a challenging workout.

Align Your Flow was developed by Natasha Rizopoulos, an advanced yoga teacher and former professional ballet dancer, who draws on both the intelligent sequencing of Ashtanga and the precision of the Iyengar tradition.
Discover the benefits of Align Your Flow and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Align Your Flow Align Your Flow instructor Align Your Flow classes benefits of Align Your Flow Natasha Rizopoulos

Budokon Yoga is a unique style of yoga that incorporates elements of martial arts training. The physical practice of Budokon Yoga is a combination of Hatha yoga flow and continuous circular rotation, with an emphasis on seamless transitions, intelligent alignment, and creative sequencing. Budokon Yoga is part of an integral Budokon system that includes not only movement arts but meditation, living arts and philosophy. Students of the Budokon curriculum will be invited to examine their beliefs, emotions, living habits, and relationships to others and their environment.

Budokon Yoga is a physically challenging practice designed to explore the body’s full range of motion. Budokon Yoga also emphasizes mindfulness and empowerment, inviting students to find freedom from fears and limiting beliefs through meditation and self-examination. Those who study Budokon at a more advanced level are eligible to earn colored belts, such as in other martial arts traditions.

Budokon Yoga was developed by yoga and martial arts master Cameron Shayne in 2000. The Budokon system quickly became popular in Hollywood, and its celebrity following helped it to spread. In 2004, Shayne founded Budokon University, which offers training and certification programs in Budokon Yoga and Budokon Martial Arts. Today, there are more than 400 certified Budokon teachers around the world.

Inner Axis Yoga is an integral yoga system designed to harmonize the body, mind and emotions and facilitate personal transformation. Developed by Max Strom from his life experience and decades of yoga, teaching, and spiritual practice, the Inner Axis system incorporates yoga postures, breathwork, meditation, self-enquiry and life philosophy to cultivate inner and outer health.

Inner Axis Yoga uses traditional yoga practices such as hatha yoga postures, breathing exercises and meditation, as well as more contemporary methods of self-inquiry and philosophy, as a path to personal transformation. The practice is intended to help students move through physical, emotional and mental blocks to achieve greater consciousness, compassion and joy.
Inner Axis Yoga was developed by yoga master Max Strom as a culmination of his life experience and deep knowledge of yoga and other personal growth disciplines.

Conscious Flow Yoga is a blend of fluid vinyasa yoga with precise alignment principles drawn from the Iyengar tradition. The practice is designed to develop a deep intentionality in each movement and action, helping to coordinate body and mind.

Conscious Flow Yoga is a dynamic and flowing practice, but time is taken to focus on integrity of alignment, both within each pose and in the transitions between the poses. The result is a practice that is physically vigorous, yet thoughtful and sustainable.
Conscious Flow Yoga was developed by Nancy Kate Williams, who trained under yoga masters Eddie Modestini and Nicki Doane.
Discover the benefits of Conscious Flow Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
Conscious Flow Yoga Conscious Flow Yoga instructor Conscious Flow Yoga classes benefits of Conscious Flow Yoga Nancy Kate Williams

Prajna Yoga is a deep and mindful yoga practice designed to develop heightened awareness of one's full Self, beginning with the outer layers of the body and mind and moving inward toward the subtler, inner space. Through asanas, meditations, and the yoga of sound, students practice sensitive inner listening, honing their somatic awareness and learning to witness thoughts and feelings. Teachers may use metaphoric and mythic language derived from ancient yogic texts to describe the body's subtle energy systems in a way that engages the students' imagination and articulates finer feelings. Classes may even incorporate dreamwork to facilitate students' self-discovery.

During a Prajna Yoga class, asanas are practiced with a meditative quality of attention. The emphasis is on the mindfulness within the pose, rather than on the physical pose itself. Exercises such as guided meditations, breathwork, and chanting help to focus awareness on the subtler layers of the mind and body. Classes may also share verses, myths, and wisdom from ancient yogic texts.

Prajna Yoga was developed by Tias and Surya Little, as a way to incorporate classical yoga practice with the the contemplative traditions of Buddhism and the subtle body wisdom of the Taoist 5-element theory.
Discover the benefits of Prajna Yoga and over 100 different types of yoga on TimetoYoga.
